Sir,

I beg to inform you that at a Council of the Watha Band held last night it was resolved:

"That the Department be informed that the Band are fully satisfied that the teacher should be appointed by the Methodist Missionary Society, and that the Department be requested to examine with care all the names on a recent petition to the contrary, many of the signatories having signed under a misapprehension of the contents, and now desiring to withdraw their names."

(Sgd.) Louis Sahanatien.

The Rev. Dr. Sutherland,
Wesley Buildings,
Toronto.
Dear Sir,-

I have received within a day or two a letter from ex-Chief Louis Sahanatien, of the Gibson Reserve, embodying what purports to be a resolution passed by the Band in Council respecting the appointment of a teacher for their school. It is probable that the resolution has been forwarded to you through another channel, but lest they may have neglected to do so I enclose a copy of Mr. Sahanatien's letter. I have informed him that while the final authority in the appointment of a teacher rests with the Department at Ottawa, yet they have accorded to us the privilege of nominating suitable persons, and that where the qualifications are regarded as satisfactory our nominations are always confirmed.

I am,

Your obedient servant,

General Secretary.

Secretary, Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, May 5, 1909.

Rev. Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 30th ult., inclosing a copy of a resolution passed by the Gibson Band in council respecting the appointment of teachers for their school.

In reply I beg to say that the petition referred to in the resolution was received by the Department and the Indians have been informed that the nomination of teachers for this school has been conceded to your Society but that you would be asked to obtain in future a teacher whose duties will be distinct from those of the Missionary.

Information has reached the Department to the effect that the wife of the present resident Missionary makes it difficult for any teacher to remain in charge of the school, and it is considered that it would be to the advantage of the school if the teacher's duties were clearly defined and the Missionary restricted.

Rev. A. Sutherland, D.D.,
General Secretary,
Methodist Missionary Society,
Toronto, Ont.

Dear Sir,

Referring to your letter of the 6th instant #152195/1 respecting the Indian School at Gibson, I would say that in all probability some of the complications have arisen from the fact that the missionary, Mr. Kendall, was not familiar with the course of procedure that ought to be taken. As the number of Indians at Gibson is so small we have always felt that the duties of missionary and teacher should be discharged by one and the same person, and this was the expectation when Mr. Kendall was appointed. But either because he did not consider himself qualified as a teacher, or more probably because he disliked the routine of a teacher's work, he employed a teacher, whom he paid out of his own pocket, and took upon himself the responsibility of making the reports, etc.

It is among the possibilities that Mr. Kendall may be transferred to another field in June next, but in the meantime I will communicate with him respecting his relation to the teacher with a view to avoid future complications.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
General Secretary.

Dear Sir,

At the present time there are four Indian Schools located on Missions connected with the Methodist Church where experienced teachers are required, namely, Gibson, Moraviantown, Chemong Lake and Christian Island, which latter school will be vacant at the end of the present calendar year.

I have applications from some four or five different parties, some of whom, I think, would make good supplies for the schools in question. Before submitting their names for appointment, however, it is important that I should know what will be the limit in regard to salary. The parties I speak of are married men, and most of them have had a number of years' experience as teachers in Public Schools. I do not know as yet what salaries they have been receiving, but I doubt if it would be practicable to secure teachers of their class for less than $500 (Five Hundred Dollars) with a house to live in.

Hoping to make satisfactory nominations in the near future, I am,

Your obedient servant,

A. Scott

General Secretary.

Secretary, Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.
Ottawa, 22nd July, 1908.

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 14th instant asking what will be the limit in regard to the salary of teachers for the schools at Gibson, Moraviantown, Chemong Lake, and Christian Island. In reply I beg to say that the salary will of course depend on the qualifications. The Department will be prepared to pay $400. to Gibson, $500. to Moraviantown, $450. to Chemong Lake, and $400. to Christian Island. The Department has no means of providing a residence at any of these places, with the exception of Chemong Lake, in regard to which you are being communicated with.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Secretary.

A. Sutherland, Esq., D.D.,
Gen'l Secy., Methodist Mission Rooms,
Toronto, Ont.

Dictated - Dr. S. Toronto, July 22, 1909.

Sir,

I beg to inform you that we have an application from Mr. John Buchanan, of Toronto, for appointment as teacher at the Indian School at Gibson. Mr. Buchanan is a married man, forty-eight years of age, has but one daughter, 21 years of age who, I suppose, will not reside on the Reserve should the appointment be made. Mr. Buchanan holds a second class certificate grade A, obtained in 1880 from the Normal School at Toronto. He has had eighteen years' experience as a teacher in various public schools though not engaged in that profession at the present time. I am informed also, that Mr. Buchanan's wife has been a very successful worker among young people, and is an excellent singer and player. I enclose copies of some of Mr. Buchanan's testimonials, and need only say further that all the information I have received concerning him is of a favorable character.

An important matter remains to be settled, however, namely, the amount of salary that we will be authorized to promise Mr. Buchanan should his appointment be approved by the Department. I presume it is fully understood that competent teachers cannot be secured at the present time on the same scale of salaries that were paid ten or even five years ago.

Mr. Buchanan's name is the only one that I am prepared to submit at this date. I am in correspondence with several others but do not think that any one of them would be more suitable than the person in question. I am your obedient servant,

Secretary, Dept. Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

General Secretary.
Ottawa, July 27, 1909.

Rev. Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 23rd inst., nominating Mr. John Buchanan, of Toronto, for the position of teacher of the Gibson Indian school.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will accept Mr. Buchanan's services and in letter of the 23rd inst. you were informed that the salary would be increased to $400.00 per annum.

Mr. Buchanan should be ready to open the school on the third Monday in August.

Your obedient Servant,

[Signature]

Dear Sir,

Regarding the school on the Gibbon Indian Reserve, Dr. Sutherland and myself (as Chairman of the District) have advertised several times and in different papers for a teacher, 2nd Class, and so far we have failed. We had accepted a good teacher, 2nd Class, Prof., but at the last he failed us also.

We are in correspondence with another..."
but have not his answer.

The salary paid being small I am somewhat in an way.

Will you consent for the time being to my opening the School with Miss

Decaire as a supply teacher until we secure one the understanding being that she's only a supply and will be replaced by a regular teacher at as early a date as possible?

Would there be any hope of securing the vacant 1st teacher with 2nd Class Normal Standing?

Sincerely,

C. W. [signature]
Ottawa, September 25, 1909.

Rev. Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 13th inst., and in reply I beg to say that the Department is not disposed to consent even to the temporary employment of Miss Decaire as teacher of the Gibson Indian school.

Taking into consideration the small number of pupils in attendance at this school, the Department is of opinion that $400.00 is a very fair salary and is not prepared to increase it.

In the interests of the Indians this school should be reopened with much more less of time, and should you not be able to submit the name of a teacher with proper qualifications, accompanied by testimonials, within a reasonable period, the Department will feel constrained to make an appointment itself, as was done last year.

Be good enough to acknowledge this letter.

Your obedient Servant,

[Signature]

Rev. C.W. Watch,
The Parsonage,
Parry Sound, Ont.

Secretary.

Rev. Sir,

On the 16th inst. the Department received a communication from Rev. C.W. Watch, Parry Sound, in which he asked permission to place Miss Desaire temporarily in charge of the Gibson school.

As the matter was urgent Mr. Watch was written to direct and I now beg to forward a copy of the letter sent him for your information.

Your obedient Servant,

Secretary.

Ottawa, September 30, 1905.

Rev. Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 27th inst. in further reference to the appointment of a teacher for the Gibson Indian school.

In reply I beg to say that on July 28, last, the Rev. Dr. Sutherland was advised that the Department would be prepared to pay a salary of $400.00 to a qualified teacher for the Gibson school, and it will adhere to this offer, but he or she must have professional qualifications.

When submitting applications to the Department full particulars must be given as to age, certificates, previous experience, etc. Testimonials should also accompany applications as the Department has not time to deal with references.

Your obedient Servant,

J. D. Mole

Secretary.

Ottawa, October 21st, 1909.

Rev. Sir,

Referring to official letter of the 30th ultimo, and previous correspondence, the Department would like to know whether you have as yet been successful in obtaining the services of a teacher for the Gibson Indian School.

If not the Department will be obliged to take steps to fill the vacancy, as it is not desirable that the school should remain closed any longer than possible.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Asst. Secretary.

Rev. O. W. Watch,
The Parsonage,
Parry Sound, Ont.
Ottawa, October 31, 1908.

Rev. Sir,

Referring to official letter of the 21st ult., I beg to advise you that no word has been received from Rev. Mr. Watch as to whether he has been successful in obtaining the services of a competent teacher for the Gibson Indian school.

It is most desirable that this vacancy should be filled at an early date, as it has existed since the summer holidays, and Mr. Watch has been asked today to report the results of his enquiries and advised that, if he has not secured a teacher, the Department will be obliged to take steps with that object in view.

The previous teacher, Miss Forrest, gave good satisfaction to the Indians and her dismissal before a successor had been obtained would now appear to have been premature and not in the best interests of the Indians, for the safeguarding of which the Department is responsible.

Your obedient Servant,

[Signature]

Rev. A. Sutherland, D.D.,
General Secretary,
Methodist Missionary Society,
Toronto, Ont.

Asst. Secretary.
Dear Sir,

In reply to yours of Oct. 1st re a teacher for the Gibson Reserve. The Applications have been forwarded to the Mission Rooms, Toronto, and will with the Testimonials from the applicant be sent into your office.

The School will be opened on Monday next.

I have advertised in several papers and had a running advertisement in our daily, and while I have received many replies, and two or three have engaged Male Teachers, offering extra inducements to the Salary yet at the least they failed to appear at their work.

However we are sending in a good teacher of our experience, and therefore more likely to remain.

Yours sincerely,

G.W. Watch
Dictated - Dr. S.

Toronto, October 28th, 1903.

Dear Sir:

I have just received an application from Miss Myrtle I. Taylor, of Parry Sound, for the position of teacher of the Gibson Indian School. It is the best application we have yet received, and unless something more promising comes to hand very soon it would seem to be desirable that Miss Taylor be appointed for the time being. I enclose her application and copies of her testimonials, as I presume she will wish to keep the originals, and will be glad to learn as soon as possible if her appointment is approved of by the Department, and what the salary will be for the rest of the current year.

I am,

Your obedient servant,

General Secretary.

Secretary.

Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

To Whom it May Concern:

This is to certify that Mrs. E. Yarwood has been an acquaintance of the undersigned for two years and two months.

During this acquaintance I have learned that Mrs. Yarwood has had considerable experience in teaching public school in the counties of Elgin and Norfolk, and I am of the opinion that her teaching would be accompanied with success. Mrs. Yarwood is a very successful Sabbath School teacher and an earnest Christian worker. The influence of her life would be decidedly felt in any community.

Taking into consideration her experience in teaching and the fact that during the last two years she has lived in contact with Indian children, would consider Mrs. Yarwood especially suited to take charge of an Indian school and would therefore heartily recommend her to the position for which she has made application.

(Sgd) Ambrose Dowsell.
Toronto, November 1, 1906

Dictated - Dr. S.

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of October 26th, referring to the appointment of Miss Myrtle I. Taylor to the position of teacher in the Gibson Indian School. I regret having to report that word has reached me this morning to the effect that Miss Taylor has decided not to accept the appointment, and I now enclose the application of Mrs. Mary L. Yarwood, of Muncey, Ontario, together with a copy of a testimonial from Mr. Ambrose Dowswell, whom I do not know, but think he may be connected with the Mount Elgin Institute. This is the only application that we have in hand at present, but I am advertising extensively and hope to receive others. If we cannot do better, be good enough to intimate if Mrs. Yarwood will be accepted as a temporary supply.

I am,

Your obedient servant,

J.M.

The Secretary, Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa,
Ontario.

Dear Sir,

I regret to say that Miss M.J. Taylor declines the Gibsons School. On the advice of your office that the salary would be $200, I stated that in my advertisements and had arranged for the position to be boarded at the Mission House for $10 per month, allowing the missionary some little compensation for its favor, and I don't think I can secure a teacher for any less salary.

I telegraphed a Mrs. Yarwood of Mt. Elgin Industrial School, Mercy, who had applied but at the time that not received her testimonials, and she replied she can go to Gibson on the 15th. But she will not accept less than $400. She holds a 2nd Class Novice Professional and 3rd Class Professional.

Ottawa, November 4th, 1909.

Rev. Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the last instant, in reference to the appointment of Miss M. I. Taylor as teacher of the Gibson school and referring to the application made by Mrs. Yarwood, who is at present at the Mount Elgin Industrial School.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will pay $400.00 per annum to Miss Taylor, but if she will not accept the position at this salary Mrs. Yarwood may be temporarily engaged at the same salary.

You will be good enough to communicate with Miss Taylor at once and obtain her decision before taking steps to engage Mrs. Yarwood.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

I regret the difficulty regarding the school vacancy on the Gibson Reserve. I have felt very foolish in the matter. We requested Miss Yardwood come up for an interview. She was induced to come by the late Agent, with the promise of increased salary. I received no notice of this, other than the resignation, which I thought was altogether for another reason.

I did my best to secure a teacher at the salary offered, but it was not sufficient. I determined to secure the class of teacher we desired.

I then heard casually that the School was opened. I had received no notice. I could not turn aside an appointment as the one made, though the young woman was of excellent character; she was not capable of teaching. I was asked regarding Miss Dewartha, but she was also competent. I felt that as the School was opened by the Agent, that he would be able to secure a teacher, and that he would be able to secure a teacher with experience, but I still felt I would not upset any arrangement made by the Agent.

In the meantime, I had been spending money getting a teacher, and had some good applications, but no appointments of teachers depended upon somewhat after-hand regarding salary, and we had thirty schools without teachers around this District, and more than half the schools occupied had teachers without certificates, who were expected to secure an appointment.

We kept Mrs. Yardwood as long as we did by agreeing to board her...
at the Mission House for $102 a month, when the lowest price board was $45 weekly. All teachers wished to be boarding at the Mission House and we have been pleased our Missionary for this privilege.

I have heard from the Board that the School is vacant again, and I was going to write them. Because when Mr. Logan visited here that he was instructed to appoint her at $300. I have no objection to this, yet I suggested to him that she had better write her appointment with the approval of the Department. The Indians will accept it, I am sure, in a better spirit if it is done this way. She has written her, subject to two weeks notice when a qualified teacher is found. I am not sure if she will accept the salary offered.

I should like to know if I am to nominate another, representing me do the Missionary Board? This will be the Society's business the appointment to pass out your hands altogether. Still I am willing to do what I can to solve the difficulty. They should suggest it is next to impossible to hold an application for a few days subject to approval, but we have been able teachers largely by telegrams in this country, the demand is so great.

Please give me the opportunity of explanation, although it better to inform you of the situation.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Sir:

Re Gibson Indian Day School.

We are in receipt of an application from Mr. James Oliver, M.A., who was for several years teacher of the Christian Island school, and at present we are holding him available as missionary teacher for the school on the Gibson Reserve. There is a specific reason why no definite nomination has been submitted to the Department.

The combined grant from the Indian Department and the Missionary Society now being paid for the work at Gibson would furnish a reasonably adequate salary for a married man. At the same time, the situation at Georgina Island is unsatisfactory from the standpoint of the Missionary Society, although I believe that the lady who is supplying there has rendered fairly good service as day school teacher. It was my hope that we might secure an efficient married man for the school at Gibson and end the temporary arrangement at Georgina Island by placing Mr. Oliver there as missionary teacher. I think that he would prefer the situation, although somewhat less remunerative, because it is more accessible and comparatively adjacent to Toronto. In the meantime, the position of the Department is secure in that both positions are covered. If we do not secure a married man whom we can recommend for the position of missionary teacher at Gibson, Mr. Oliver will be nominated for that school and the present or some similar arrangement continued at Georgina Island.

Sir,

As indicated in my report for the Quarter ending Dec., 1916, I am sending you a short supplementary letter re the attendance at this school since I took charge in the latter part of 1916.

The first thing I noticed on my arrival here in September last was the distance from both school & Church of most of the Indians' houses. This I at once inferred would militate greatly in unfavorable weather against a good attendance, especially in the case of the School, which of course depends on the younger members of the community, and always numbers a fair proportion of girls among its pupils. My inference proved only too correct; though I little anticipated then the dreadful state into which the roads quickly fell during even a short period of wet weather. During such a time, and also in the bitter days of winter, which is very severe on these uplands, it is almost impossible for any save the more robust children to travel often to School. Little children (and there are many on the roll) can't come; and it is hard on the elders ones to do so.

During the warmer days of the Fall the attendance was much better. In one week (Oct. 7-12 inclusive) it ran as follows: Oct. 12, Th. 13, Wed. 16, Th. 18, Sat. 20 - the last day being an uneventful one - and so on till Winter came, when the attendance fell with the thermometer and the snow till the usual attendance read as low as 10-15. Oct. 27-31, Nov. 3-7, Wed. 11, Th. 13, Th. 15, Th. 17, Sat. 19 - a very worse. Then "bad roads" and "bad frosts" in a short time became in the parents' mouths...
the stock excuse in a schoolhouse continued absence from school during the season of bad weather above indicated.

Of course my excuse serves as Indians as a reason for his or her child's absence from school. I have yet to meet an Indian with a real excuse of honour or duty, so you cannot use this as a cover. Children is either non-existent or spoiled, and hence at best when handled with a very tender hand. We have no truant officer, and unless the Indian Act were strictly carried out, we are just as well without one.

I have spoken in almost with extreme earnestness on the duty of parents as to the education of children; but it seems only waste of breath; for every Indian's own inclination is a law unto them in matters where no punishment follows the offense.

The sluggish, inert, spasmodic nature of these Indians, young and old, lies as a serious barrier in the way of all progress. Morality is a humorous factor in the life of these people, who are Indians to the finger-tips, despite the fact that most of them have almost white skins. The skin is the only thing white about them, I regret to say, in most cases.

I am writing healthily and pessimistically; for I am doing my best for my charges here. I gave ten prizes of books at the Christmas gathering, and also candy, &c. I wrote to the agent to ask if there were any fond to do this year; but got no reply.

I gave three books, &c., to encourage the scholars—only nine who attended only.

I am sorry I had to delay my report; but all the holidays I have been ill.

Illness of my wife—an attack of pleurisy coupled with a touch of influenza usually passes all defects of voice.

(Signed)

Sir,

In connection with the subject matter of the enclosed petition I beg to report that while there last week I looked into the merits of the case.

The settlement of the Gibson reserve is divided into two, one known as the "Black Lake" situated on the western part, and the other as the "School-house" Settlement. The children of the former settlement have now to travel over 2 miles to get to the regular school across a wilderness of forest and rocks, traversing of which, even at best of seasons, is a source of anxiety to the parents as to the safety of their children, but during the inclement weather the trip is more hazardous for the little ones. There are 15 children of school age in the Black Lake Settlement. (List enclosed).

If the Department considers the advisability of granting the request of these Indians, a school could be opened in the home of Chief Peter Strength who is prepared to allow the use of one of his rooms, 21 x 10, well lighted with four windows and has an entrance of its own, for $8.00 a month, which will cover heating, sweeping the room and the use of an organ. The benches now in the old abandoned Methodist Church nearby could be utilized for the use of the pupils and teacher. The Chief's place is about as convenient a place as any for that purpose in the vicinity. Miss Mary Strength, age 18, daughter of the Chief, and an ex-pupil of Mount Algin Institute, could be engaged for the

D.C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Superintendent General
of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
for the 4 months beginning 1st January, next, for $25.00
a month, as assistant to the regular teacher, Mr. Jones,
who is willing to supervise her work. As most of the child-
ren are small, young and in the primary grades, it is thought
that anyone having an ordinary public school education, like
Miss Strength, who I may add is also quite a musician, could
satisfactorily fill the position for the time being. The
school material, excepting a blackboard, would not have to
be purchased as the supply on hand at the regular school
could be used. The school in fact will be a subsidiary to
the regular one. The total expenditure involved in such a
move would not exceed $135.00 for the 4 months.

Years ago the school on the reserve used to be
held alternately every six months on these two settlements,
but was found unsatisfactory and the practice discontinued.
The present school is doing splendid work and is apparently
appreciated by the Indians, as shown by the attendance of the
children considering the distance and awful roads they have
to travel to get to the school. Last year one of the pupils,
Alex Desaire, passed the entrance examinations with honors,
and is now continuing his studies in the high School at
Barry Sound. The only complaint offered by the teacher was
lack of punctuality on the part of the pupils in getting to
school in time for the opening exercises and he thinks that
if the school had a large bell and rung regularly half an
hour before opening, this would be remedied to a large extent.

The teacher, Mr. Jones, an Englishman, about 40,
appears to take keen interest in his work as teacher and
missionary. He evidently has the confidence and support
of the Indians. The practice of appointing teachers on
this reserve, as well as on some of the other reserves, in
the dual capacity of teacher and missionary, may have some
commendable points in its favour. It, however, seems to
me to be a source of handicap to the attainment of anything like full measure of success in either sphere, and should be discouraged as much as possible. This opinion I may add, is shared by all those engaged in that capacity, in the case of Mr. Jones, while he appears to be attached to the religious side of his work, yet I cannot help thinking that were his efforts wholly given to one line of work, he would attain far greater success. Mr. Jones is engaged in teaching the boys in manual training and his wife is gratuitously giving her services to teaching the girls in domestic science. Mrs. Jones, a refined English lady and worthy of better environment, feels extremely out of her element on the reserve, and for the sake of her husband's usefulness it would appear advisable to give him every consideration in the matter of transfer to another school, not so isolated as Gibson on the occasion when the Missionary Society releases him from his present incumbency.

I have gathered the following observations from the remarks made by different Indians during the discussion on the timber question and it can be seen that they have grasped the situation rightly. They have learned the value of education; realized that it is the only means available with which their children can confidently expect to make good for themselves; that they now have to live like white people; face the struggle of life with the same equipment as the whiteman and that the greatest asset in this struggle is the acquisition of practical knowledge of the English language. These Indians have got beyond the childish notion so popularly current in the minds of Misoka brethren, viz: that an Indian with his imaginary "treaty rights", will be an Indian as long as the sun shines, etc. From every indication such a delusion is a thing of the past with these people.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

Your letter of 15th received with thanks.

In reference to the night school of which you made mention I beg leave to say that the prospect now before us of the general progress of the work here is very promising indeed.

I now take pleasure in answering your questions.

I purpose of planning to use the main school house.

The furnishings are quite suitable except that we should require two good hanging lamps for lighting. Also I would need the cupboard and new teacher's desk which I believe have been ordered some time.

The only cupboard I have now is a small one built under the chimney.

The only desk I have is an old wooden rough structure used here many years.

There would be needed several additions in material such as books, etc., which list I attach on a separate page.

I would also ask for the school bell as early as convenient.

I have been feeling around since
received your letter & I find the night school would be popular. The chief himself has stated that if opened he will attend.

I am of the opinion that if started at an early date during the progress of the forward movement which is going on here, such an enterprise would be heartily welcomed & a new sense of the importance of sending the children to the regular school would be awakened in the parents.

Esteemed Sir,

Let me take the liberty in writing a few lines to our Honorable Sir, to explain the state of affairs in our School concerning the incompetency of the school teacher.

I do not doubt that Miss Black, our school teacher, is a good and educated woman. But she cannot keep order in the school. Children does what they like, sing and whistle and play. She cannot hold them into submission. And on account of this they cannot learn—in the least.
She cries and weeps more than the children. Can keep over her scolding and then she will turn the child out doors to go home. The child's parent would keep them at home in a few days after she will report this child's absence for staying away from school. Who is going to get the blame not the children and not the parent but herself. And another thing she does not look after the children from using bad language I passed alongside the school house one day. I listened to the noise inside. I thought the children had the recess. No. I overheard one pupil reading his lesson between the intervals of the din of laughter and whistling and yelling and running around the room.
Now your Honorable Sirs consider these facts carefully and recognize that what I am telling is the truth and anybody can corroborate my statements just the same. I am not running the school teacher down any other way, only save these facts, what I already stated.

Let me hear from you soon

I remain Yours Truly

Dear Sir,

Perhaps you will pardon me for referring to a condition of affairs which I stumbled upon when I visited the Reserve on Tuesday of last week. I was wending my way along, intending to call on Miss Strength for a while before dinner. When I got as far as Miss Black's school, I called for a minute to tell her that she would likely have company that afternoon. It was then that I learned that Miss Strength was not teaching and that her school was closed.

I drove on as far as Mrs. Commandant's, where I had dinner. I got some more particulars there about the trouble in the school. It seems that it was all over Miss Strength's own brother. He thought he could do as he liked since it was only his sister that was teaching. But she thought that he had as much right to obey her as the other pupils had, and whenever she undertook to chastise him, he simply made his way into the other part of the house, where he found ample protection at the hands of his mother. Miss Strength, seeing the folly of trying to control a school under these conditions, and having a certain amount of desirable spunk, closed the school, left home, and took up the duties of cook in a camp some distance away.

I did not call upon the Strength's as Mr. Strength was not at home, Miss Strength was away, and Mrs. S. cannot speak English.

An early settlement of the difficulty is earnestly desired by the parents, and the Chief, it is thought, should take immediate action.

Yours respectfully,

H.R. Scovell, J.P.S.

Reverend Sir:

I beg to inform you that our agent at Parry Sound, who recently visited the Gibson Reserve, found that there were very few children attending school. On making inquiries, he found that the reasons therefor were as follows:

1. There is a general complaint from all the members of the band that the teacher, Miss Black, is not able to control the children of 10 years and upward.

2. The members of the band claimed that there was no use in sending their children as they did as they liked and worried the teacher so much that she often cried at the way they carried on.

3. A number of the parents admitted to the agent that Miss Black is a good teacher, but they claimed that she lacked the power to enforce her authority. The members of the council requested that a younger teacher be engaged. The agent states that Miss Black seemed to be in poor health and too nervous for the position she holds. He recommends that a change be made, otherwise the education of the majority of the children will be badly neglected.

As this school is conducted under the auspices of the Methodist Church, I am submitting the above for your consideration. We do not desire to be unfair to Miss Black, but reports as to her lack of control of the children have been received at intervals during the time she has been teaching at this school, and it is considered advisable, in view of the interests of the work, to dispense with her services if another teacher can be secured.

I shall be pleased to have your views in the matter, also, if a change of teachers is made, whether a qualified successor to Miss Black can be obtained. Your early attention to this matter will be appreciated.

Dear Sir:-

Since receiving your letter of November 29th, re a successor to Miss Black, as teacher of the school on the Gibson Indian Reserve, I have been trying to secure the services of another teacher - preferably a Missionary Teacher - but up to the present have failed to get in touch with anyone whom I think would meet the requirements.

In a communication from the Rev. Arthur Barner, received this morning, he says that he would move slowly in dismissing a teacher in the middle of the year for the following reasons:

1. These complaints from Indian Reserves die down and unless the evidence is conclusive that the change is wise we sometimes leave ourselves and the people worse off instead of better.

2. It is difficult to get good teachers at this time of the year.

3. The teacher there must live alone in the mission house. I would hesitate to send a girl without experience to that task in the winter. The summer is the time for testing out in these things."

In view of our inability to find a successor to Miss Black, who would take charge of the Gibson school at the beginning of the New Year, would it not be better to allow her to continue in her present position until next summer, when we will do our best to secure a Missionary Teacher to succeed her?

Awaiting your reply, and wishing you the Compliments of the Season,

I am,
Very faithfully yours,

J. D. McLean, Esq.,

Dear Sir:

I am in touch with a young man - 29 years of age - Frederick George Steeds by name, who has recently come to Canada. He was a Lieutenant in the British Army, and was transferred to the Indian Army. He was demobilized on May 23rd, 1921, and since then has been St. Luke's College, Exeter, England, training as a school teacher. He took his examinations in April 1925, but before they were over he developed the flu and his temperature rising to 103, he was not able to write on all the subjects set for the examination. Mathematics, I believe, was the only one upon which he did not write. A letter from the Educational authorities in England shows that he passed on all subjects but Mathematics.

He is willing to serve as Missionary Teacher on the Gibson Reserve. He is married, and has one child, and as there is a mission house on this Reserve it would be an advantage rather than otherwise that he is not a single man. He has the ministry in view and impresses me very favourably.

The Rev. Marshall Hartley, who is Secretary of the Methodist Brotherhood in England, writes of him as follows:

"He has teacher's certificates. He has had quite a remarkable career as a preacher while he has been in the army and has been the means of the conversion of officers and others. Clearly, as I gather from personal talk with him, his ultimate destiny is the ministry and in this I am sure you will gladly guide him. It is a long time since I have met a young man so obviously fitted for that work and willing to serve in any part of the world."

If you will agree to his appointment as Missionary Teacher on the Gibson Reserve, I will arrange with him to undertake the work there. Providing you concur in my proposal, what would his salary as teacher be?

Awaiting your reply, I am,

Very faithfully yours,

C. E. Manning.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter, File No.22-1-1, bearing date of June 7th, 1924. This letter was not received at the Mission Rooms until this morning, July 9th. The date of this letter must surely be a typographical error.

You write about F. G. Steeds, the Missionary Teacher on the Gibson Reserve. I am surprised to have the information that you give me to the effect that during the month of May the school was in operation only eight days, and only five days in the month of June.

It is not long since the Indian Agent called me by phone when in the city, to urge that something be done to retain Mr. Steeds' services on this Reserve for another year. The Indians appointed a representative to come to Toronto to see me, to make sure that he would not be removed. Now, to have the statement from you that the Indians have requested that a qualified teacher - who will be relieved of the duties of a missionary - be engaged, is a surprise to me.

Is it not possible that Mr. Steeds' efforts to establish better moral conditions on the Reserve have something to do with this agitation against him? According to his report he has taken drastic measures with some of the Indians there! I have written him to ascertain why the school was in operation only eight days in May and five days in June.

I am leaving for my holidays on Monday next, and do not expect to be in the Mission Rooms until about the middle of August, and if you have any further report to send me in regard to Steeds' relation to the Gibson Indians, I would like to have it, if possible, by return mail.

I am,
Very faithfully yours,

Toronto 2, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

I have just received your letter of November 1st re Inspector Johnson's report of the Day School here. It comes as a surprise somewhat to me as on this particular visit he remained only a short time with us. He inspected some reading classes and said there was an improvement in the children's reading. I might just say that the children are a little nervous of Mr. Johnson, and read in a lower tone than usual. Indian children, in my twelve years experience in Indian teaching, do not speak so freely or clearly as white children. They have their Indian language before they start school and this makes it more difficult to learn the English, and causes their articulation to be rather broken. The attendance here is rather irregular.

In reference to appearing apathetic about the work, I might simply state, that like my father, a university man and teacher, I have always enjoyed teaching school and have been interested in the profession. However I may appear, I have always had fair results in my work. In the fifty years of school work here at Gibson I have been the first teacher to put through an entrance scholar. In the three or four years here I have put through two scholars. I voluntarily offered to teach them the first two years of high school work to fit them for training for nurses. They came and did very good work. I have an entrance class this year. I also started a fair in connection with the school. We receive Eaton's school prizes with silver cup as well as other special prizes. The fair work includes writing, drawing, painting, agriculture, sewing and composition. Our work has been taken to the County Union Fair and we have carried off some First and other prizes there. Also some families have asked that I remain on here until their children get educated. I do not see how in these above examples of my work in the school that I have been apathetic in my dealings with the pupils. I do not say Mr. Johnson is aware of what I have just been stating. The Indian work is peculiar in itself and one has to adjust oneself to them to get the best results. This I am attempting to do to the best of my knowledge. With the above evidence I think I am obtaining fair reward for my efforts with ten years experience in white schools. I find
it more difficult in Indian work though I think much of the work here measures up fairly with the average white schools.

As an ordained minister and normalite I feel that my work is part of my religion and I will ever endeavour to obtain the highest reward in the work of my school. I have faithfully carried out any suggestions which Mr. Johnson has made in the school work in his inspections.

I trust that with this rather lengthy Epistle I have given you a truthful statement of the work being carried on here at Gibson Day School and that you are in a position to understand more fully how the work is going on here.

I remain,

Yours respectfully,

(sgd.) John A. Ward.

Dear Sir:

Mrs. Sommer and myself are missionary and teacher on this Reserve. We are new in work among Indians, being absolute greenhorns on our arrival here July 1934. We have worked away there however and have become very much interested in the work and in the Indians. We feel however that we need to know more about them than we do, in order to be of the most service in our work.

We understand that all Indians or tribes rather, have agreements or treaties with the government. We have no idea what the treaty with these Indians is, or how their affairs are to be managed.
If it is available to us, we would very much like to have all the information about these Indians that is obtainable, that we may more perfectly understand their and their relation to Canada's government and institutions, etc.

We find that the people spend way too much time arguing over things no one knows for sure about, and it seems to us that there must be information somewhere (surely with the Dept.) that would help clear up many matters at present not cleared up and never will be unless they know more about their own business. It seems just that they should know what are their rights and what aren't their rights; and that we all really should know how their affairs should be managed.

Thank you very much in advance for any help you can give us.

Yours Truly,

Chester Sommer.

Dear Mr. Beaton:

As the Indian Department's complaint concerns me, I feel I should write a few lines in answer too.

Quoting the Indian Agent (Mr. Daly) about this, he remarked, "I guess Mr. Johnson (Inspector) had a chip on his shoulder the day he called". At any rate I am deeply grieved over his untimely report from here.

He came the last of September. I showed him the new time table for the school asking for help if it seemed unbalanced. He said it was all right. I had changed some of the afternoon subjects to the 11 a.m. to 12 a.m. period in the morning, subjects in which Mr. Sommer gives special help such as music, singing, public speaking, reading, etc. (In this he is unusually capable and very successful.) I explained the change, that after this, when Mr. Sommer did help it would be in the morning instead of in the afternoon as previously.

When Mr. Johnson called it was the second morning of Mr. Sommer's help at school since school started in September, although last year he helped me more often in the afternoon periods.

Since coming here we have succeeded in getting four to study for the "Entrance". Only one in the Reserve has succeeded in the school's history. We were quite pleased to think we had persuaded four to even try. Last June Mr. Johnson came and I asked regarding the pupils writing the Government exams. I told him I was rather worried over three of them trying white people's standard exams in a strange school (Eala) etc., and that three did not know their work thoroughly. He said, "Send them anyway to give them an idea of what it is like whether they pass or not". I sent them. They all failed. Mr. Johnson, in turn, wrote to Ottawa, (we were shown an extract from his report) "Four pupils wrote. All failed. Fault partly due to children and partly to insufficient knowledge of the Ontario examination requirements." — Why wouldn't Ottawa wonder how we were running the school by such a remark? I thought it quite unfair on his part.

Mr. Daly told us that they were expecting trouble as Ontario is trying to get the "say" of Indian Ontario schools. So far it has failed. Such things as these in Mr. Johnson's mind would spur him on, I presume, to send in an absolutely ambiguous report.

We are running a heavy schedule of school work, manual training, sewing, knitting, public speaking, special singing, soft ball and soccer games for the school age children. I found the schedule to stand up under physically without help. We are conscientiously doing our best for the school (not omitting the community) which makes the complaint harder to
bear without hurt. I feel very badly in having a complaint come in to your office over my seeming neglect of work, where, on the other hand, I am trying to do my very best to be an all-round help to the Reserve.

May I be allowed to suggest that you phone Mr. and Mrs. Douglas, 1529 Bathurst St., Apartment 127? We hired them as supply this summer and they must have gained some idea of our work from the children, while here.

Again I say I am very sorry over the trouble and misunderstanding due to the untimely report. Mr. Johnson has been and is always encouraging and quite enthusiastic over being answered by the children (he says) for the first time in his several years inspecting.

We would very much like it if you could at some time visit Gibson Reserve and/or sorry your heavy program is too rushed to allow you to do this.

Yours respectfully,

(signed) (Mrs.) C. O. Sommer.
Bala, Ontario,

Dear Mr. Beaton:

As Mrs. Sommer is writing you in some detail about the school work, I shall devote my attention to your request for information regarding my teaching qualifications. The usual first question that is asked is "Have you an Ontario Teacher's license?", and my answer is "No". I have only those qualifications which my particular training and study in religious education, and my experience in teaching Sunday School classes at Summer Camps and Teacher Training classes has given me, along with what intelligence and soul I possess.

My best answer is "by their fruits ye shall know them", but you have to know the fruits to know the qualifications. We know that the school has gone steadily ahead. It is much nearer the standard it should be than upon our arrival. Subjects are being taught, which before our coming the children were not expected to be able to learn. There is a higher percentage of attendance. The school children openly profess to like attending school now, whereas they used to dislike it. There have been only two children in the history of the Reserve (we are told) who ever tried their Entrance examinations before our coming. We have encouraged four to write and I think that is a good sign. Mr. Johnson, also Mr. Tipper (the one who conducts the school fairs here) have commented on signs of advance and qualities of personality, not known and marked by a board of strange examiners.

Mr. Johnson knows all the above, and I am surprised that he should send in an adverse report of the school here, considering all the advance which he knows has been made. The only explanation I can offer is that he may have a personal grudge against us because we let him know we were not satisfied with some of the marks given some of our entrance class, and he is responsible for that.

Mrs. Sommer and myself carry on extra classes with the boys and girls in woodwork and sewing respectively. These are entirely voluntary on our part and they take up a good deal of our time and mental and spiritual energy. We do not begrudge the time, but we would at least not be unfairly criticized for our work. In the subjects which I have been teaching in the school, Mr. Johnson has acknowledged that the quality has been steadily improving ever since we came. In general, may I conclude and summarize that we are convinced that the school, not to mention the whole Reserve, is getting better service under the arrangement we have been carrying out than if the minister had to teach and be responsible for all the work up here.
Another factor motivating Mr. Johnson's conduct might very readily be that he imagines that besides what is allowed for teaching, I may be getting an extra thousand dollars or so as missionary. If so, I can understand this galling him when many of his teachers receive only $500.00 and upwards.

May I say in winding up this subject that I am very sorry there should be a troubling of the waters unnecessarily — at the Department, your office or here. I trust that they will be quieted down again satisfactorily, and to the best interests of the common good.

Mrs. Sommer and myself join in thanking all who were instrumental in our having a very enjoyable and profitable summer. Best regards to you personally and success and happiness in your new work.

Yours very sincerely,

(signed) Chester Owen Sommer.

Sir;

I respectfully offer the following suggestions, which I think would be of benefit to the running of schools in this Agency,-

I would suggest that before any teacher is employed for this Agency that she be asked to fill out a form stating her qualifications and notified that her appointment is for the teaching year (10 months) and that if she wishes to continue, and her services are satisfactory, she has to apply for the position from year to year.

I have found in the last 15 years here that the teachers applying for positions in this Agency, have the idea that it is a life job and there are two cases in point where the teachers have shown their utter disregard of this office, one was at Lower French School when Mrs. Munson was there, and the other is at the Magnetawan Indian Day School at Byng inlet where Miss O'Meara is.

If this is done it would be a good thing for the teachers, a good thing for the Department, and a good thing for the Agency, and everyone would know just exactly where they stood.

The consideration of the Department to these remarks will be very much appreciated in this Agency.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

REPORT FOR THE MONTH OF FEBRUARY, 1943.

February has been marked by an epidemic of 'Flu or Grippe all over the country and the Indians have not escaped, but as usual, have had rather more than their share. School attendance has been very poor and in some cases schools had to be closed owing to illness of both teacher and pupils. I have been glad to learn that we are to have a teacher for the Ryerson School on the Parry Island Reserve, which is now scheduled to reopen on March 4. This school has been closed since last June and a good many of the youngster have been running wild, although many who live near enough to the Village of Depot Harbour have been attending the white school there. This school suspension will perhaps help the parents to realize the benefits offered by the Department's schools and induce them to more urgently take advantage of such benefits.

I am enclosing herewith letter received from Mr. J. O. Harris, missionary teacher on the Gibson Reserve. I regret very much to be obliged to make an adverse report on Mr. J. O. Harris, Missionary teacher on the Gibson Reserve. On a recent visit to the Reserve, shortly after the reopening of the school following the Easter holidays, I found Mrs. Harris in charge of the school. I inquired for her husband and she advised me that he was in Toronto taking two weeks leave. Mr. Harris had not mentioned the matter of leave or made any application to me in this respect.

I am bound to say that Mr. Harris had made an excellent school teacher but that otherwise he appears to be very erratic and has had no success at all in dealing with the adult Indians on the Reserve. He has kept me in constant hot water settling his disputes with the Indians and in many ways his conduct has been open to question. Questions have been raised as to his handling of church funds, a matter which I have not delved into, as I consider it the business of the church authorities and, while I would hesitate to say that there has been anything wrong along these lines, there appears to be no doubt but that his handling of various sums of money entrusted to him has been, to say the least, extremely careless and questionable in a man of his position. I have had various complaints also from local merchants about the difficulty of collecting his personal accounts.

When Mr. Harris returns, I will interview him and advise you further as to what excuses he may have to offer of being absent without leave.

Samuel Devlin,
Indian Agent.
I will begin with what I consider the most important part of our work for the Indian - the educational programme. The greater part of our work will be finished when we have taught the Indian to live as we do and to think as we think. While this process of education cannot be completed by the ordinary school curriculum, none the less the schools must supply the groundwork. I find that the average Indian professes a lip service to the principles of education for his children, but in actual fact opposes it by what at the best might be termed apathetic indifference.

As an instance I might cite the case of the day school on the Parry Island Reserve which I was obliged to close for two months during the winter for lack of fuel. There are probably 12000 acres of this Reserve covered thickly with good fuel-wood, but I had to use all my powers of persuasion to get enough of it cut and hauled in to ensure continued operation of the school. Poor attendance is another bug bear with which we have to contend. It is interesting to note that the schools which have the best teachers and who are the strictest disciplinarians have the best record of attendance. It is my opinion that in the education of Indian children we should have the best brains of the teaching profession and that any extra expenditures to secure this would be repaid a thousand-fold. Our present rates of salaries paid to teachers of Indian schools, coupled with all the social and other disadvantages of life on an Indian Reserve leave us, when we come to engage teachers, with the dullest of the profession when we should actually choose from the flower.

Samuel Devlin,
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ontario.

Further to my recent report on the missionary situation at the Gibson Reserve, I have to report that Mr. Harris was absent from his duties for one week. Apparently his wife had been having an affair with a young Indian boy of the Reserve and Mr. Harris has taken her to Toronto for psychiatric examination and treatment.

The whole affair has left us with a decided loss of prestige amongst the Indians and I consider that his influence as a missionary and teacher is definitely ruined, at least at that point. Mr. Harris was continually involved in quarrels with the Indians there and as I have mentioned before, there were questions raised as to his handling of church funds and he was also continually taking on financial obligations which he found it difficult to discharge and I have on several occasions been asked to bring pressure to bear on him to pay his debts.

I received a wire on Saturday last from Mrs. Clyde W. Matteson, missionary teacher on the Gibson Reserve, resigning her position there effective December 17. I have since then seen Mrs. Matteson and advised her that it would also be necessary for her to forward her resignation to the Home Mission Board which she has already done.

Mrs. Matteson has not been very successful in her position on the Gibson Reserve and has become decidedly unpopular there. She is not at all the type for this sort of work but we had been so unfortunate with our teachers there recently that I had decided to give her some time to settle down and get acquainted in the hope that matters would improve. I was, however, very glad to get her voluntary resignation as things were going from bad to worse.

Mrs. Matteson complains very bitterly that her work was interfered with by Mr. J. O. Harris the last missionary we had at that point and who is now, I believe, employed in a similar position on the Saugan Reserve. I believe that Mrs. Matteson has some grounds for her complaint as it would appear that Mr. Harris has made several visits to the Gibson Reserve recently. His wife, from whom he is estranged, has also been a recent visit or to the Reserve and I have been told that they have both said to various people there that Mrs. Matteson would soon be out and that either one or the other of them will be back to the Gibson Reserve to stay. This, of course, is only hearsay but I intend to write to Mr. Harris and advise him that he should stay away from this Reserve altogether as his visits there cause me a lot of trouble. I would also write to Mrs. Harris but I have not her present address.

With regard to Mrs. Matteson, I might say that Dr. Johnstone had been called in to treat her for a cold and his report to me was that the Mission House was very dirty and that Mrs. Matteson's person and clothing were also in a filthy condition. The main difficulty would be transportation, provided also that the Bala school would accept them as pupils which I believe they would do if they have sufficient accommodation.

There is a small covered truck on the Reserve but I am very doubtful if all the children could be transported in one trip in this vehicle. There are twenty-odd children who had been attending the school on the Reserve. The greatest distance to be covered would be about 12 miles and there would possibly be occasions during the winter when they might have to miss the occasional day as the road on the Reserve is difficult to keep open during the winter.

In reply to your letter of February 10 I would advise that I have been looking into the matter of the transportation of the children from the Gibson Reserve to the white school at Bala. There are two small trucks owned on the Reserve which had been mentioned for the transportation job. One of them, however, is too small and while the other, which is a panel truck, might accommodate the number of school children, that owner and driver is not a person whom I could recommend for such employment. He has obtained an ordinary driver's license but I know that his eye sight is very poor and I do not myself think that he should be permitted to drive any kind of a vehicle. In order to carry out this transportation business, it would be necessary for him to obtain a chauffeur's license and I am very doubtful if he could do so. In any event if he did obtain such a license, I would still not feel that the children would be safe in his charge.

It may be possible, however, to obtain a bus service from outside the Reserve and I am looking into this.

Dear Mr. Ferrier:

I have to report that the teachers of this Agency have asked that their cheques for term ending June 30 be here by the 25th of the month.

This request seems reasonable as some of them have to go a long distance and will be leaving on the midnight of the 30th. The 26th comes on a Saturday and they would like to do some shopping before they go home. I can arrange with the Manager of the Bank to cash their cheques. The Bank will be closed before the train comes in but the Manager will oblige us in that way. Mrs. English and Mrs. Earl Taylor cannot get in on time for the Bank on Saturday.

I should state that Mrs. Taylor is handing in her resignation as teacher at the end of this term and will not be available for next year. I have spoken to the Rev. Father McPadden here to try to get a Teacher as all the Indians at Maganetawan are Roman Catholics. He will let me know in good time what he can do. Miss Smiley of Ryerson Indian Day School has asked permission to close school on the 25th, and as she has a very long way to go and has given excellent service, I would recommend that her request be favourably considered. Owing to a resolution passed some time ago by the Gibson Council regarding a new teacher being appointed I would suggest that the Dept. ask the Missionary people at Toronto to make a change at Gibson. I know that Mr. Joblin has been in the service of the Dept. for a number of years but somehow or other he doesn't seem to fit in at Gibson. This is only a suggestion on my part. I think that Mr. Joblin will be glad of a change.

Please say if I can expect the cheques on the 25th.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

In reply to your favor of the 30th ultimo regarding some repairs required to be made at the Gibson Indian School, I write to say that I shall have the necessary repairs referred to completed before the re-opening of the school after the summer holidays.

In regard to the dissatisfaction of some of the Gibson Indians as to the situation of their school, I write to say that I have already had some correspondence with Napoleon Commandant (who appears to be the leader of a certain faction of the Band who desire the removal of the school) on this subject, and I have pointed out to him that the school is located at the most central part of the Reserve, on the corner of Lot 11, Con 5, so that I do not think the Department would consent to any change being made. I shall accordingly, as instructed in your favor of the 30th ultimo, inform Commandant of your decision in the matter.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

I beg leave to acknowledge the receipt of your letter, Mr. Mickle & Symment & Son.

I may say that last November when I was at Sahonaton School house, holding a meeting for the nomination for Chief. The band was fully represented twenty-eight out of thirty-four members of adults were present. And the principal discussion at the meeting was the matter of repairs to School, which is in a great need of repairs more so than any School building in the Agency. I advised the Chief to get a practical Carpenter to make an estimate of the quantities of lumber and shingles required, as well as nails and paint. And have a resolution passed in their regular Council after he had found out what the cost of the material and labor would amount to. And that I had no doubt but the Department would consider their request. The first intimation I received was a memo giving the number of pieces of lumber required and in a few days Mr. Mickle, Symment & Sons account followed. I may say that their prices are more moderate than what the same material can be purchased in the town of Parry Sound.

Gibson School.

I may mention that the name of Antoine Dewashe has been suggested to the Department as being a reliable person. I examined the school house and grounds at Eaton Place, and find that the trouble is that the road passes close to the school house and the windows being low allow the children when studying the school work to feel very much when it was painted last June. They had not used any shelter on the walls (hence the trouble).

The water lies all around the building, it will be necessary to get a drain run from the building and some gravel put around it. The ground wants clearing off some. The road diverted and a fence put up to keep the teams and wagons away.

I think it would take $100.00 to put the grounds in shape and build a fence around, and it will cost $50.00 to paint it.

I can get Francis because to fix the grounds and build fence—and Albert Commandant could do the painting if kept. Think it preferable to have the Indians do it—waiting for Commandant I am sure.

In reference to the schoolhouse I take this opportunity of recommending that a great thing for this reserve and in my opinion a great necessity is a brighter and better schoolhouse. Either on this spot or close by could be erected a house which would attract the scholars and with the necessary improvements quite an advance could be made in our educational activities here. This schoolhouse is out of date, very poor appearance and very dismal. It is used for Council, entertainments, etc., etc., and is old and unattractive. In my opinion it would be an advantage to have a schoolhouse which would be up-to-date, attractive and used for a schoolhouse. The present building could be used for institutional purposes which we are anxious to prepare for next winter, where games, recreation, lectures, etc., could be enjoyed. Mrs. Jones and myself would make the physical culture and gymnastics a special feature.

The present house is badly in need of painting in and out, floor renewed, etc. (fair condition for aforesaid purposes but to encourage the day and night schools I certainly call your attention to the great need of a new schoolhouse. I am quite sure that attendance, punctuality, &c., would be greatly improved and a new interest aroused and the whole idea of education among the people placed upon a higher plane and the Dept. would be well repaid for the expenditure and effort. I am also persuaded that in the interests of the young and rising race we should have two classrooms.

I would ask the Dept. in the event of their acceding to my request to appoint Mrs. Jones, my wife, to instruct the primer, who with myself is willing to make the education of these people a decided success. When all the children are at home there should be an excellent primer class. I refer to the main school, and Mrs. Jones could do this work very well. I would also desire the Department to authorize the permanent continuation of the sub-school which I am glad to state has proven a great success. The teacher, I believe, is devoted to her work and desires continuation.

I would also ask as a great necessity that the night school be continued until June as I hear that some more are desirous of starting but camps and bad roads, etc., have prevented a regular attendance yet.

Sir,

I beg to report on Gibson School as requested in above letter.

The closets mentioned are in good shape, they are sided on the outside and painted, matched lumber inside and shingled roof with ventilator in each one. All they require and which I would recommend is a coat of lime whitewash inside. There is no need of screened approaches as they are twenty-five feet apart.

As to the urgent need of a well in the school grounds, there are three wells within one hundred yards of the school and as there are only a few children attending school it would be much better to use the water from one of these. If a well was put in the school grounds it would be so little used that the water would become stagnant.

In the last paragraph of the above letter you state the teacher's residence needs painting etc., As the teacher's house belongs to the Methodist Missionary Society I asked the teacher what he meant by reporting the house being in need of painting and he said he intended the school house. While I think the building is not very bad it might be well to give the inside a coat of paint during the Summer holidays and a new floor would improve the School House although it is not too bad. The present floor is laid with 10 inch pine lumber. If a new floor and platform were put down in hardwood it would cost at the present time $250.00.

The most needed thing in this school are seats as quite a number are broken. If the Department
Sir,

will look up where the seats were purchased and let me know I could get some repairs for them and have them fixed up. I think they were bought about 1911 or 1912.

Mr. Jones seems to have a mania for ordering supplies. He started a night school lately but no one is attending, the most he had was three and he has a cupboard filled with books etc., and lamps that cost a lot of money and are not used. He also got saws, planes, hammers etc., and sewing material and I find they have never been used either but he says he can get anything he wants from the Department and is now talking a new school house. I venture to say that this school and equipments including the closets as better than 75% of the rural white schools in this district. I am quite sure it was a mistake to change the truant officer as he has now a number of the Indian families against him and to use his own words "are boycotting him." The man (the Chief) appointed truant officer was up at my office last week along with Frank Decaire, another Indian, of the Reserve, wishing to have Jones removed as teacher but would like to retain his services as preacher as he has put them into debt by purchasing a $500.00 imitation pipe organ and I am sure a $150.00 one would have been all that was necessary.
Ottawa, April 24, 1920.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 21st instant regarding the repairs which the teacher stated in his annual report were needed to be made to the closets and school building on the Gibson Reserve.

In reply I beg to say that it is considered, in view of your report, that screened approaches are not required. It might be well to give the closets a coat of lime whitewash inside and this work should be done at very little expense. If you consider it advisable to do so, you may have the closets whitewashed inside. The work should be done by one of the Indians.

It would not appear necessary to provide a well for the school, in view of the fact that there are three wells near the school from which water can be obtained.

The Department is not prepared to have a new floor placed in the school at the present time.

You should furnish an estimate of the cost of having the inside of the building painted, stating the cost of the paint required and the amount it would cost to have the painting done.

The desks supplied this school in September, 1911, were ordered from The E. N. Moyer Co., Limited, Toronto, and consisted of 4 No. 5 double individual, 4 No. 4, 2 No. 3 and 2 No. 2, as well as 2 No. 2 rear seats. Any broken parts of the desks could, no doubt, be supplied by this firm and you should ascertain what parts are required and order them and have the desks placed in good repair.

Alexander Logan, Esq.,
Indian Superintendent,
Ferry Sound, Ont.

This letter informs you that I closed school Friday noon Sept. 31st and that school was closed all last week and Monday of this week opening again Tuesday 11th October.

The reason for this is that it was absolutely necessary to have school repairs and cleaning done all of which should have been attended to during summer holidays. When I returned in September nothing had been done except the weeds had been
in the school yard
I started in to teach Tuesday
after Labor Day into a dirty
school and repaired desks
and window panes
out door repairs not done
to caretaker on the job.
The former caretaker
Mr Laforce was offered
forty-dollars but refused
to take it for less than fifty
dollars. However he was
away up to Port Carling
all summer and did not
return till after I came back
so he could not attend to
the school cleaning during
the holidays. The son Phillips
Laforce was at home but they
did nothing.
The caretaker did not the
slightest repair in school
or out so when things got broken
accidentally sometimes a little
repair might have saved them
from going too far.
Leaf 2 -
Of course I know the caretaker did not get enough pay for the amount of work he had to do in connection with the school so he can hardly be condemned for not doing any extra.

Mr. Dewasha has undertaken the repairing & cleaning of the school and repairing outside everything is not complete yet but there is enough done to begin school on Tuesday.

I will send you the expenses bill later when more work is completed.

The repairing & cleaning did not begin in the beginning of the week for Mr. Dewasha did not wish to undertake the work till he got authority to do so from the Chief through Monday. The Chief told him to start in on Wednesday, but he had to go to Bala for things and so could not begin till later and no cleaning could not start till
Saturday as pipe chimney had
to be cleaned first. Besides
other repairs—
Mr. Dewar will take over
the job of caretaker for the
sum of fifty dollars a
year but will not take it for
less.
Personally I think the job is
worth that amount of money.
He will look after the school
for the present till a caretaker
is hired for 25 cents a day.
If he is hired as a caretaker
at the sum of fifty dollars,
this charge of 25 cents a day will
not be reckoned to his account.
May I be allowed the privilege
of suggesting that when
the caretaker is hired, he to be
given specific definite directions
as to his duties among these
that a pail of fresh water
be put into school every morning
and also that the fuel—
Buildings be carefully inspected & kept in a sanitary way, and then be inspected often and in co-operation with teacher and pupils we all try to help.

I would like some law to be enacted to the Band whereby they would be under obligation not to spit around either in church or in the school house when they meet for any social or business function. Things along that line have improved but the improvement is not thorough yet.

I have spoken about it and I have tried to have it stopped but I want this reform to be thoroughly rooted into them.
I would request the Dept. of Indian Affairs not to deduct anything off my teaching days owing to school being closed as it was work which should have been done during holidays. It is a lesson to have things done at the right time and thus save time and money.

OTTAWA, October 14th, 1921.

Madam,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 10th instant, informing the Department that you had to close the Gibson Indian Day School for several days on account of repairs being made.

In reply I beg to say that your action in this instance is approved, but I would point out that the Department does not desire teachers to close schools during the regular teaching period, unless for urgent reasons. Salary will be allowed you, but you should state on your quarterly return the days school was closed, and the reason therefor.

Regarding the appointment of a caretaker, I beg to say that Chief Strength, who visited the Department recently, recommended the appointment of Xavier Laforce. The Department has approved of his appointment, with salary at the rate of $50.00 per annum, payable quarterly. The Chief was requested to inform Laforce of his appointment, and to also inform him that it is expected he will perform his duties as directed, and besides the ordinary duties of caretaker he is to provide the drinking water required for the use of the school, and that he is to sweep the class room after school hours instead of in the morning.

Chief Strength was also instructed to have the following repairs made, viz:

- 2 panes of glass put in, desks repaired, stove and stove pipes cleaned.

The painting of the inside of the school will have to remain over until next summer.

It is noted that you have arranged with Mr. Desasha to undertake the work of repairing and cleaning. You may also arrange with him to have 2 locks, with keys, installed; one on the wood shop and the other on the porch; also the hinges repaired, or new ones put on, and also have any repairs required made to the side walk to the boys' closet.

I will be pleased if you will keep a careful account of all expenditures for the purpose, and forward these accounts, in duplicate, to Mr. Superintendent Logan, who will certify the same and send them to the Department when, if satisfactory, payment will be made.

Your obedient servant,

Miss Mary A. Black,
Teacher, Gibson Indian Day School,
Sahaniatien,

Answering yours of May 4th, 22-1-5, I have been to Gibsen Reserve, and examined the school and school grounds, also the fencing. I find that the following is required to put the building and fencing in proper condition:

The wood shed, which is attached to main building, thus— as a lean-to, must be reshingled. The roof of main building must be repaired, a new ridge board put on. There are two locks required for doors of school, and two latches for toilets. There are 25 pests and one small gate required for fencing.

The work can be done by members of the band, and shingles can be bought at Balsam, lime for chimney at Parry Sound, and paint and nails, at Parry Sound. The small gate can be bought at Parry Sound.

Next year this building will require a new floor. I would recommend that repairs be started right away, so that everything will be finished in good time for opening of school in September.

Ottawa, October 15th, 1923.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 9th instant, regarding the desks required for the Gibson Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say that the teacher asks for 6 double desks, and it is noted that you recommend that single desks be supplied. Kindly state whether it will be necessary to supply only six single desks, or whether 12 single desks are required, in order to provide the same seating accommodation as the 6 double desks asked for by the teacher.

When the sub-school was in operation during the winter months several desks were supplied for the use of this school. There was also a quantity of school material supplied. As this school will not likely be in operation, it is thought that the desks could be transferred to the Gibson school, and, if this were done, it might obviate the necessity of purchasing more desks. All school material, which was on hand when the school closed, should be transferred and used at the Gibson school.

If it is absolutely necessary to purchase desks for the Gibson school, you should state the sizes and number of each size required. Desks are manufactured in the following sizes, viz:
