Ottawa, November 8, 1924.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Gibson Indian Day School, recommends that screened approaches be erected in front of the water closets. He also states that the boys' closet is in need of repair and is quite unsanitary. He further recommends that the stove in the classroom be jacketed and fitted with a ventilating pipe.

I shall be pleased if you will arrange to have the boys' closet placed in a good state of repair and thoroughly cleaned. If you consider that screened approaches should be erected in front of the closets, you may also have this work done. The Inspector states that he explained to the teacher the question of having the stove jacketed and fitted with a ventilating pipe. If you consider that this would be an improvement on the heating arrangement you may arrange to have the work done. It may be that Mr. Joblin, the teacher, could arrange for the labour in having the above work carried out, and either he or you could purchase any materials required. Properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, should be forwarded covering any expenditure incurred.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Sir,

With the coming near the Xmas season, and as the children and the schools of this Agency except Henvey Inlet, have attended extra well, the thought has occurred to me that, perhaps, the Dept. would like to encourage the children to attend school, by assisting the various bands, the teacher, and myself, by giving a donation to our Xmas tree fund. I don't know if there are any funds available for this purpose, but I am sure that such action on the part of the Dept. would be appreciated by the children, their parents, the teacher, and myself. Even $10.00 for each school would bring a glow of happiness to the faces of the youngsters, which would more than reward for the expenditure asked.

Trusting that you will consider this application favourably,

I have the honour to be,

Sir:

Your obedient servant,

Agent.

Ottawa, December 3, 1924.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 29th ultimo, requesting that a grant be provided as a donation towards the Christmas Tree fund at each of the Indian Day Schools in the Parry Sound agency.

In reply I have to say that the Department will provide a grant for each of the above schools, as follows:

- Shawanaga: $10.00
- Gibson: $10.00
- Ryerson: $10.00
- Maganetawan: $5.00
- Lower French River: $5.00

If you consider that the schools at Henvey Inlet and Moose Deer Point should receive a grant, the Department will approve of an expenditure of $5.00 for each school.

You may arrange for the purchase of the various articles or gifts to the above authorized amounts for each of the schools. Properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the expenditure for each of the schools, separately, should be forwarded.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

John M. Daly, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Extract from report of Inspector McRoberts on his inspection of the Gibson Day School on November 26th, 1925. Original on file 22-1-6.

"........ The girls' closet is satisfactory; the boys' closet is in bad condition. "droppings" on the seat is badly chewed by porcupines. A new seat is needed here. The girls' closet, kept clean and painted, is not chewed.

"A cord running through a pulley and fastened at lower window sill should be attached to each upper window sash so that the sash might be lowered for ventilation. Locks should be provided for windows when school is not in session. A cord and pulley for "man-hole" cover in ceiling would also assist in ventilation.

"A serious crack in the box-stove should be repaired before damage occurs. The stove should also be provided with a metal jacket screen at sides and back to save pupils seated near from being too hot while others at a distance are cold."
Ottawa, December 16th, 1925.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Gibson Indian Day School, has drawn attention to the condition of the boys' toilet. He states that a new seat is required.

He also recommends, with reference to the windows in the school building, that a cord running through a pulley and fastened at a lower window sill should be attached to each upper window sash, so that the sash might be lowered for ventilation, and that locks should be provided for windows when school is not in session. He also states that a cord and pulley for the "manhole" cover in the ceiling would also assist in the ventilation of the building.

He further states that there is a serious crack in the box stove which should be repaired before further damage occurs, and that the stove should also be provided with a metal jacket screen at sides and back to save pupils seated near from being too hot while others at a distance are cold.

On the occasion of your next visit to the Gibson School, I should be pleased if you would enquire into the matters referred to, and, if you concur in the Inspector's recommendations, you may arrange to have the work mentioned carried out. Any work undertaken should be performed at the lowest possible cost. The Department will leave this matter in your hands to have the work as suggested by the Inspector carried out if you consider it necessary to have same performed. Properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, should be forwarded covering any expenditure incurred.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Dear Mr. Ferrier,

I just got back yesterday morning from an inspection of the schools. As stated to you in a letter yesterday, I am very well pleased with Miss O'Meara and Mrs. Munson, and I believe that they are going to be a success. They had their little trouble in starting up, and the houses were not as tidy as they might have been and a lot of the stuff that should have been there, such as dishes, were broken and not reported home by the teachers.

In having a look around, which I took time to do, I find that there will have to be some improvements made still around next summer and I am writing at this stage of the game so that you will be able to get in your estimates sufficient to cover the cost of the following:

Gibson school requires paint outside and inside. It is very dirty and I am very dissatisfied with the appearance of the school. I would not like either you or Mr. Macookin to come and see the school as it is at the present time. The inside is very much in need of painting and the outside as well.

The teacher's house at Pickeral should not be allowed to go past the summer without painting. The school, I think, will do for another year.

The school at Magnetawan Reserve should have been painted last year and is surely very much in need of it now.
The school at Moose Deer Point requires painting both outside and inside.

Now, Mr. Ferrier, the reason for me bringing this to your notice is this, I have tried to keep the schools standardised by having them fit for inspection by any of the officials from headquarters at any time. Mr. McGookin can tell you about the schools at Magnetawan and Moose Point, that they are in need of painting.

I have conscientiously tried to keep down costs as much as possible, in fact I have come to the conclusion that perhaps I have been a little too tight re supplies for the teacher's houses and so forth. When I mentioned that some of these schools are isolated and out of the way to a certain extent, I think it is up to the officials of the Department, that is, you and me and everybody else, to try and make them as homelike and comfortable as possible so that we will be able to keep a good class of teachers. Then there is the dignity of the Department in owning these buildings, to be upheld. Hence my reason for bringing the matter before you at the present time so that if possible, you will be able to put through sufficient to cover the cost of the necessary improvements by the end of the financial year, next March.

While at Lower French School, I looked the situation over re a boat and the dock. There is no dock there. There is a floating platform, which I must give Mrs. Munsen credit for. She has had it moved down to the river; when I was there before it was high and dry. There are a lot of round boulders and the water is shallow where they have to land. As the water is low at the present time this is a good time to have this work done. I have given instructions that a place 12 ft wide be cleared and sufficiently far out in the river so that in the event of a blow coming up in the river the boat will be away from the rocks. I should explain that the river is wide here and squalls at this time of the year will come up and blow the boat away from the dock which causes it to hit these rocks.
I observed that Mrs. Munsen had the boat tied, bow and stern to the platform, but when the platform is floating it moves too, so you can quite easily understand how it is possible for a boat to be pounded against the rocks.

I have satisfied Mrs. Munsen that the boat will be seaworthy for this season, so will try to keep this expense down until next Spring, but it will be necessary to have a good boat next spring. I will make arrangements with Scott's Boat Livery for a good strong boat which has been very slightly used and that I can procure for $50.00. This is a bargain that I am getting because of the business that I give to Scott's Boat Livery. The boat is well worth $75.00. This expenditure for boat can go into next year's estimates.

About a gallon of varnish will be required for the bedroom and sitting room floors and linoleum for the kitchen in the Magnetawan Teachers house. It appears to me that they have been splitting wood in the kitchens by the look of them, and as both these teachers Mrs. Munsen and Miss O'Meara, are quite enthusiastic about their work I think it behoves us to make them feel at home and comfortable. I would therefore recommend that varnish for the sitting room and bedroom floors and linoleum for the kitchen be procured. This building is finished in British Columbia fir pine and at some future date the walls should be varnished in the meantime it will do but the floors will have to be fixed up.

I trust Mr. Ferrier, that you will understand the reason for this letter. These things that I am asking for at the present time are absolutely necessary and if the painting is not done the buildings will not be a credit to the Department and I should feel very vexed if they were allowed to go any longer than next summer without being looked after, and I am sure the officials of the Department if they were here with me would concur with my ideas.
Thanking you for your kind consideration in sending me what I believe to be good teachers. The man at Parry Island is on trial, and I think with careful handling he might be a success.

Yours truly,

John Daly

Sir;

I beg to report that I have made an inspection of all the schools in the Agency and after very careful consideration of the financial situation and the scarcity of funds at the disposal of the Department, enclosed please find an estimate of the painting of three schools out of the six in the Agency, in need of paint.

All six schools are in need of painting to keep them in repair, as well as from a sanitary point of view, but because I know of the shortage of money in the estimates for purposes such as this, I am submitting only three, and would strongly recommend that the Department try and arrange for a grant for the painting of these three schools. As the times get better, I would hope that the Department would be able to arrange for the painting of the other three schools, perhaps next year.

In sending in the estimate to the Department in mine of May 12th, T-3689, I omitted to put in the wood shed, and toilets. I am including same in this estimate. Tucker Brothers of Parry Sound have submitted the enclosed estimate, and considering the distances that they have to cover, it is to my mind, an exceptionally reasonable estimate for work which I know will be well done.

The distance from here to Magnetawan Reserve, on the railroad is 39 miles, and one mile from Byng Inlet Station to the reserve; the distance from here to Gibson, is 35 miles on the railroad, to Salla, and eight
to the school in the Reserve; the distance from Parry Sound to Moose Point, via gasoline speeder is 45 miles.

I would strongly recommend that this estimate from Tucker Brothers be accepted, for the painting of these schools. The reason for me recommending that these schools be painted, is that, the Byng Inlet School, is very much in need of painting and is a landmark on the Reserve. It can be seen from the train, when passing, and there is just the difference at the present time, of this building not looking good. The school at Gibson is a centre of interest to the tourists driving to Black Lake, and the school at Moose Deer Point, is visited by a great number of tourists. These three schools should be painted this year, in order that they may be a credit to the Department.

The consideration of the Department in this matter will be very much appreciated.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

My explanation, in letter sent forward that the Indians do not make a good job of painting, is one of the reasons why the schools require to be painted properly with a good foundation. I am taking into consideration the necessity of giving the Indians all the work possible, but in doing this in the past, I have discovered that the buildings suffer and the expenditure is not justified for the job that they make, and another reason I feel like refraining from giving the Indians the job of painting is this, that if I could get a regular job done, not patchy, by a good painter, we would have a good backing for future jobs whereby the Indians can make no mistake.

The prices as sent forward from Tucker Brothers seem to me to be very reasonable for the job that I know they will make. The Tucker brothers have their business here in Parry Sound, and they do pretty nearly all the Government work that is to be done here. They are doing the new post office. It is my opinion that the Department would be well advised to accept Tucker's offer for doing these schools.
By having Tucker Brothers do the job, we will have a good job, and if any future painting of the schools is done, there will be a good foundation for the Indians to work on, although my experience with the Indians is that they do not make a good job of painting.

Trusting this explanation will be satisfactory and that Tucker Brothers offer will be accepted.

I have the honour to be,
Sir,
Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Agent.

Sir:

Following mine of July 7th, I would draw the attention of the Department to my recommendation that Robert Stock, who is a returned soldier with a family of seven, receive two more rations. Montgomery told me that he wanted to discuss the matter with me before doing anything. I explained to him that Robert Stock who is a returned soldier, and a member of the Band, with a wife and six children, and Isaiah Dewasha a married man with eight children, and both in receipt of relief, should have the privilege of doing this work. I explained to Montgomery that I would be responsible for them making a satisfactory job. He said he would send their names forward to Dr. McGibbon.

Owing to the conditions in that section of the country at the present time, and the need for assistance being granted to these men and their families, I would strongly recommend that they get this job of painting the school, woodshed and toilets at Gibson Reserve, and that it be given to them as soon as possible.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Gibson Indian Day School, states that the platform in front of the school needs repairing, also that the front gate is missing, which allows the cows to get in, making the playground unfit for play. He also recommends that several loads of gravel be hauled, to fill in the open ditch by the water closets. He states this ditch is unsanitary.

I would request that you arrange to have any repairs required carried out to the platform in front of the school, and, if necessary, a new gate supplied and installed. Regarding the gravel, it is considered the Indians, themselves, should be able to haul a few loads of gravel to fill in the open ditch referred to by the Inspector without cost to the Department.

Any expenditure incurred should be kept to the lowest possible point, and should be covered by accounts, in triplicate, which should be certified by you and forwarded for payment.

Sir:

Yours of June 8th, 22-1-5 received re report of the Public School Inspector at the Gibson Indian Day School. In reply I have to state that I knew the platform required to be fixed up, but was letting it go as long as possible in my endeavour to keep down costs.

I do not agree with the Inspector that the ditch at the toilets should be covered up, as I find it is necessary to drain that section of the School grounds, but I have to state that the aprons around the toilets have been heaved by the frost, and should be fixed up, and some of the boards are broken off the aprons. If the Department will grant a requisition for this, I can have it done at very little cost.

The next time I am in the Gibson Reserve, I will endeavour to have a bee, and have a couple of loads of gravel hauled to scatter around the toilets, but not to fill in the ditch. When I am talking to the Band about having a bee to have the gravel hauled for this purpose, I will explain to them that they are not paying anything out of the Band funds for their education and in that way perhaps some of the members of the Band will volunteer to haul the gravel.

Re the little gate; I do not think the cows are doing any harm in the school yard, it is only a small gateway. The large gate on the main road is kept closed, but if the Department thinks that a gate should be put on, I would suggest that when they grant the requisition for the fixing of the aprons of the toilets, I could have a handy man make a
little gate out of rough lumber to serve the purpose. This would not cost very much, as near as I can guess the cost of the lumber and a day's wages, or at the most two days' wages would cover the cost of this.

The opinion of the Department in this matter will be very much appreciated.

Should the officials of the Department see fit, they can ask Inspector McGookin and he will tell them that the building and the grounds are in pretty good shape, and I know that the Public School Inspector visits schools not half as good as the school in the Gibson Reserve. It was painted last year and is in pretty good shape for such an old building.

I would be much obliged if the Department will grant a requisition to get the work done as suggested by me.

The consideration of the Department at their earliest will be very much appreciated.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.,

Sir;

While on a recent visit to the Gibson Reserve, I was informed that the school roof was leaking, and since then I have had a letter from Rev. J.A. Ward, School teacher, that it is getting worse.

I was endeavouring to put this off until spring so that we could examine the roof thoroughly but it appears that something will have to be done to fix up the roof now. It is very hard to make an estimate of the exact cost, but I presume they will require two bundles of shingles, and it would take at least two men one day to fix it.

I would recommend that this be attended to right away and would respectfully request the serious consideration of the Department, at their earliest.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Agent.

JMD/EK.
Ottawa, February 12, 1934.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 8th instant, reporting on the repairs required to the roof of the Gibson Indian Day School building.

In reply I have to say that you may arrange for the purchase of the quantity of shingles required - approximately two bundles - and for the labour in carrying out the repairs necessary at the present time to prevent leakage. No unnecessary expense should be incurred. After the work has been completed, please forward an account, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred in the purchase of materials and for the labour employed.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

J. H. Daly, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Parry Sound, Ont.

Parry Sound, Ont.,
June 9th, 1934,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario,

Sir:

Replying to yours of June 7th, 22-1-5

I was at Gibson Reserve the other day and was very much surprised to see the screen of one of the boy's toilets leaning up against the fence. I had a lot of running around in the reserve and when I was coming away I did not see the man, James News, who I get to do these repairs.

The toilets require to be fixed up and I think this could be done for $10.00 or $15.00. Most of the men are working on the road, and I refrained from asking them to do any work around the school, as they were making money outside of the reserve, and keeping down the costs of relief. I expect this work will be finished in the near future when I shall be able to get lots of men to do the work.

I understand from what Mr. Ward tells me that he will be leaving at the end of this term, and a new man will be coming in. Should the Department wish me to go ahead with these repairs, I would like to have everything in good shape when the new man comes in.

A reply at your earliest convenience will be very much appreciated.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Agent.

Parry Sound, Ont.,
July 11, 1941.

Dear Sir:

I am enclosing estimate of the cost of repairs to the Gibson Indian Day School. This school is gradually becoming a ruin and I think that the repairs which I have indicated are very necessary this year. If the year's estimates are not sufficient to take care of this work I would be glad to know just what sum might be made available and we could perhaps do a portion of the work this year and complete the job next year. I might say that I do not anticipate anything other than minor repair bills for any of the other schools in the Agency this year.

Yours truly,

Samuel Devlin,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Enc.
Ottawa, July 16, 1941.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 11th instant, with reference to repairs required at the Gibson Indian Day School.

In the current year's appropriation an amount of $200 was provided for repairs and improvements for the schools in your agency. We have already authorized an expenditure of $20 at Henvey Inlet and $81 at Ryerson. This leaves a balance of approximately $200 still available.

I note from your letter that some of the work could be done this year and the balance completed next year. I would therefore appreciate hearing further from you regarding what can be done with the amount that can be spent, namely $200. When forwarding a list of the material, you should state the name of the firm from whom you are obtaining prices, because, if the materials cost over fifty dollars, it will be necessary to purchase them through our Purchasing Branch.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Mr. Samuel Devlin,
Indian Agent,
Parry Sound, Ont.

Dear Sir:

In reply to above letter I beg to enclose revised estimate of repairs for the Gibson School, making the amount approximately $200.00 to be expended this year. I will put off shingling and painting of this building until next year and will include in my estimates an amount to cover this.

I am enclosing estimates of repairs necessary to the various schools in this Agency. Some of these estimates may appear high but the fact is that various repairs which were put off during the war years have accumulated.

The largest amount is for the Gibson Day School, the bulk of which is for fencing the school grounds and the erection of two new toilets. Authority was granted last year for these toilets to the amount of $112.00. I was unable to proceed with the work last year due to both the shortage of material and labour. I propose, if possible, to have it done this summer but a review of the situation shows the costs to be considerably increased due to prices of both material and labour.

I would be glad to have these costs for the various schools passed if at all possible but should it not be possible to pass on the amounts requested because of non-inclusion in the estimates, you might indicate what amounts would be available for expenditure on the various schools and I will have as much as possible completed this year and the balance next year. Your prompt attention to this will be appreciated as I would like to have the work completed during the summer holidays.

Samuel Devlin,
Indian Agent.

Sir—

Referring to your letter, addressed to me, dated 17th July, File No. 152.1947— instructing me to see if the Severn Indians would assist in putting up a small house for a teacher residence—I beg to say that during my recent visit I learned that a building committee of three members of the Band had been appointed—a site suitable for the purpose had been selected on lot 11 Con. V contiguous to the School House. An application was made to purchase the house of the late Mr. Rivers from his widow—who has again married—and to remove it to the site of the Teacher House. It was thought that the house in question could be bought for $400. The Band consented to raise the proposed building as well as to aid in its removal. The balance of the amount asked for would, it was estimated, pay a contractor for completing the hemped structure.

I examined the house it was proposed to purchase and found it a substantial well built log house 20x22 in size and 1½ story in height. It was floored up and down stairs with very good lumber. The upstairs floors were hewn timbers about 3½" and the walls downstairs were lined with very good planed lumber.

I believe that the structure could be moved piecemeal.
With the exception of the roof which I fear would be injured by removal and would necessitate the reshingling of the new house.

If your Department approves the proposal I am writing to the holder of Peter Rivers' land named Mr. Smart of the Bay of Quinte Reserve (Chelmsford P.O.) and began at what price she would dispose of her claim on the house.

I explained to the Building Committee that the chief difficulty that I saw in the way of purchasing the structure above mentioned, would be getting some contractor to accept the responsibility of buying, removing and erecting the house for $150, the amount asked for, and which I understand your Dept. will grant. If your Department were to purchase the structure and the contractor subsequently throw up or failed in his contract the loss of the purchase money would be sustained. Perhaps, however, a conditional purchase might be made from Mr. Smart and throw the risk of a default by the contractor on her. At present the house is of no value whatever to her and if not sold will only rest in the middle of her former husband's clearing.

Sir,

When visiting the Indians in the Township of Gibson last autumn I was convinced that for the stability and success of the work both educationally and religiously among them, it was important that we should add an element of permanence by erecting a house in which the missionary-teacher could reside. I talked over the matter with Chief Beaire, and he now informs me that he brought the proposal before the general Council on the 7th inst.. At that meeting Xavier Laforce, whose farm is across the road from the school, agreed to donate half an acre free, and an additional acre and a half on receiving the cost of clearing the land. The two acres to be a site for the proposed mission house. This offer by Laforce was concurred in by the Council.

I now write to enquire if the same regulations obtain at Gibson as on other Indian Reserves; that is, could Laforce give an absolute title to these two acres, or would we have simply a virtual title of occupancy from the Department so long as we used it for the purposes above indicated. We would prefer the absolute title, but of course desire to act in harmony with Departmental regulations.

I am, Sir,

Your Obedient Servant,

A. Sutherland
General Secretary.

Sir,

Referring to the proposed transfer of a number of Indian schools to the sole control of the Department of Indian Affairs on the 1st of July next, I beg to submit the following facts in regard to some of them:

1. The school at Gibson has been without a teacher for some time, and we have not been able to secure one whom we could confidently recommend. This has arisen partly from the fact that there is no accommodation on the Reserve for an unmarried teacher, and there is no house in which a married teacher could reside. A short time ago one of the Indians, Xavier Laforce, agreed to surrender two acres as a site for a teacher's house; this is on a farm immediately opposite to the school house. Arrangements were made for Mr C.E. Fitten, Land Surveyor, to proceed to Gibson on the 5th of June for the purpose of surveying the two acres, after which a sketch with distances properly marked would be forwarded to the Department. In order that a suitable teacher may be procured for the Gibson Indians, it seems to be not only desirable, but absolutely necessary that a house be erected for him to live in, and I respectfully submit this matter to the Department with the earnest hope that the necessary accommodation will be provided.

General

All materials used in the different departments to be first-class of their respective kinds, and all the works to be performed in a thorough and workmanlike manner.

Figures on the Plans to be taken in preference to measurements by scale.

EXCAVATION, Etc.

Excavate for cellar whole size of Kitchen Extension, and build good stone walls to same.

BRICKLAYER.

The chimneys are to be built with good, hard, well-burnt red bricks, and chimney tops are to be carried to the heights above the roof, as shewn; to rest on brackets 2 ft. 6 in. from ceiling line. The smoke flues of 9 in. x 9 in. are to be formed in the most careful manner and well parged. All necessary stovepipe collars and stoppers to smoke flues to be placed 1 ft. 6 in. from ceiling to centres of flues. Three partition stones will be required.

CARPENTER AND JOINER.

The Cottage is to be built on cedar posts 10 in. in diameter, placed 4 ft. in the ground. (Give alternative Estimate for stone foundation throughout).

The framing timbers are to be of pine and of the following dimensions ——

| Plates, principal posts, interties, and door and window posts | 4 x 4      |

| Ground floor joists                              | 10 x 2     |

The building is to be framed and braced in a strong and workmanlike manner. The sills are to be solidly rested on the posts, and halved and primed at the angles. The exterior corner posts and the principal posts are to be well spiked to the sills and plates.

Bracketting

Fix substantial bracketting for chimneys.

Roof

Roof of Cottage to be strongly framed and made of pitch as shewn on Drawings. Properly trim roof for chimney shafts and where else required. The plates of Cottage to be in as long lengths as possible, and dovetailed at angles. The common rafters are to be well notched and
spiked down to the wall plates, and also to the valley rafters and ridge pieces at 20 in. centres. Cover the roof with 1 in. rough boards which are to be well nailed to the rafters. The ridges of roof to be covered with 2½ in. rolls, to be carefully laid on 4½ in. × ¾ in. saddle boards. Sir,

Referring to previous correspondence respecting the erection of a teacher's house on the Gibson Reserve, I beg to say that plans and specifications were sent through the Rev J.J. Ferguson, of Bracebridge, to the Messrs Brown Bros., a reliable firm of builders in that place. They have furnished an estimate of cost of building according to two different plans, and I enclose their estimate, and am sending to the Department a copy of the plans in question. It will be seen that in both cases the houses are of the cheaper class; but I think if either plan is adopted it is very desirable that the building should be erected on a stone foundation, which will involve some extra cost, also that the rough outside boarding should be covered with building felt before the clapboarding is put on. "Plan B." would look better and be more comfortable, if covered with clapboarding as provided for in the specification rather than with upright boards and battens, as shown in the plan. If the Department prefers a story-and-a-half building, differently arranged, we can supply plans for the purpose. Anything further we can do to facilitate the erection of the proposed house will be cheerfully undertaken.

I am, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

OTTAWA, 7th October, 1901.

The Secretary:

As directed by the Deputy Minister Rev. Dr Sutherland was requested to submit plan and specifications for a teacher's house on the Gibson reserve, with an estimate of the proposed cost.

The accompanying plan and specifications have been received from Dr Sutherland with a builder's estimate which shows that a building constructed after plan "A" would cost $1253.75 with stone foundation and $1010.00 if put up on cedar posts; while one after plan "B" would cost $950.00 with stone foundation or $720.00 if built on posts.

Plan "B" would I think afford sufficient accommodation and for the small number of rooms provided would have a much better appearance than if the building were a story and a half instead of the cottage style.

If the Department approves of either of these plans the Methodist Church is prepared to go on with the building under the arrangement proposed which was to wait for payment until the money is voted.

I understand that they have a good schoolhouse at Gibson, which should last for a number of years.

PROPOSED REGULATIONS IN RE SCHOOL TRUSTEES.

RESOLVED:

That there shall be elected for three years in the same manner as is provided for the election of Chiefs (Section 75 of the Indian Act) three school trustees;

That in the case of a vacancy occurring by death, resignation, or otherwise, it shall be filled by election of another trustee or trustees for the unexpired portion of the three year term at the time current;

That the duties of the school trustees shall be,

1. To appoint a time and place for an annual meeting of the Band for the discussion of matters appertaining to education,

2. To report to the Council on the condition of the houses, properties, premises, and state of education on the Reserve at least once a year, but as much oftener as they deem necessary,

3. To assist in promoting regularity of attendance,

4. To accompany the School Inspector or other inspecting officer in visits made to the school.
RULES AND REGULATIONS.

The council of the Algonquins of Golden Lake in the Province of Ontario enact, subject to confirmation, under Section 76 of the Indian Act, the following Rules and Regulations, viz.,

1. Religious Denomination of Teacher.

The teacher of the school upon the Reserve shall be and no alteration of this rule shall be made except by the Band in Council, after at least three weeks' notice has been given at a regular meeting of the Band in Council.

2. Public Health.

The Council may appoint by resolution one or more persons to visit each Indian residence within the Reserve during the first week of every month, or to receive reports concerning, or take notice of matters dangerous to the public health; and such sanitary officer or officers shall notify such owner or occupant on whose premises there is found any filth, offal, carcass, or putrid or other offensive matter to remove or bury the same; and any owner or occupant who, on being notified, fails within a reasonable time to remove such filth, offal, carcass, or putrid or other offensive matter, shall be liable to a penalty of not less than 50 cents or more than $5.00, or to a term of imprisonment not exceeding ten days.

3. Order and Decency.

A general council of the Band shall be held.

The adult male members of the Band shall be entitled to take part in, and vote on all matters before
before the Band in Council, and shall observe, keep, and perform the rulings of the presiding officer as to all matters of order and decorum, and if any person present at such Council shall misbehave, by using improper, obscene, or blasphemous language, or by being intoxicated or in other ways disturbing the peace, he or she shall be liable to be ejected by the presiding officer, or by his order, and also be subject to a fine of not less than 50 cents nor more than $5.00, or to a term of imprisonment not exceeding ten days.

4. Intemperance and Profligacy.

The Chiefs in Council shall recommend a member of the Band to be appointed as a Dominion Constable, whose duty it shall be to enforce the law, and also the rules of the Band, and to repress intemperance and profligacy by lodging information against offenders, and such constable shall receive all notices of fines and penalties which by law are payable to those laying information and complaints.

5. Trespass by Cattle, Pounds, &c.

(a) No horses, mules, sheep, pigs, or other cattle shall be allowed to run at large on the Reserve, and it shall be lawful for any member of the Band to take or drive away such animal or animals at large or trespassing upon enclosed lands to a pound established by resolution of the Council, and place it or them in charge of the pound-keepers.

(b) A pound shall be established, and a pound keeper appointed by the Council.

(c) It shall be the duty of such pound-keeper to feed, water, shelter, and properly care for all horses.
horses, mules, sheep, pigs or cattle placed in his charge,
and for each day in which such pound-keeper fails to feed,
water, shelter, and properly care for any animal as
aforesaid placed in his charge he shall be liable to a
penalty not exceeding $5.00, or to a term of imprisonment
not exceeding ten days.

(d) The following poundage fees may be collected:

(e) Any horses, mules, sheep, pigs or cattle im-
pounded and remaining in pound for four full days may be
disposed of by the pound-keeper at public auction, but
written or printed notices of the sale shall be posted
at the council house and at not less than three other con-
spicuous places on the Reserve for two days before the
sale, and if the horses, mules, sheep, pigs or cattle
belong to persons who are known, or not residing upon the
Reserve, the owners shall be notified in writing at least
two days before such animals are offered for sale.

(f) The pound-keeper shall, in the event of the amount
realized by the sale of any animal being insufficient to
pay the fees and expenses incurred of impounding and sale
be entitled to recover the deficiency from the owner or
owners of the animal (if known) in a summary manner
before a Justice of the Peace.

6. Public Works.

Every able-bodied Indian resident upon a Reserve, and
every non-resident owner shall, at a time appointed by
the Council, contribute days' labour on work
public work of the nature described in paragraphs "f"
and "g" of Section 76 of the Indian Act upon the Reserve,
or in cutting wood for the school, as may be indicated by
by a supervisor appointed by the Council; and every Indian resident upon the Reserve, and every non-resident owner who fails or refuses to contribute such six days' labour in person or by substitute, or to pay to the supervisor a sum of in lieu thereof, when called upon to do so under the authority of the Council, shall be liable to a penalty of $3.00 or a term of imprisonment not exceeding ten days for such offence.

7. Location of Lands.

As soon as convenient a general council of the Band shall be called for location of the land in the Reserve conformable to the provisions contained in Section 16 of the Indian Act, and the occupancy of such Indian shall be determined by a vote of a majority of the members present at such Council, which determination, if deemed unfair by any claimant, may be appealed against when it is submitted for the approval of the Superintendent General, as by law required.

8. Repression of Noxious Weeds.

Every Indian owner or occupant shall keep his premises clear of noxious weeds, and any such owner or occupant who fails to remove any such noxious weeds found growing upon his premises within fourteen days of his being notified to remove them by the Indian or any person thereunto authorized by the Council, shall be liable to a penalty of not more than $5.00 or to a term of imprisonment not exceeding ten days unless the fine be sooner paid.

MEMORANDUM FOR THE ACTING SUPERINTENDENT GENERAL OF INDIAN AFFAIRS

Touching the continuance of Mr. O'Brien in the position of Teacher of the Golden Lake School, the undersigned has the honour to inform you that the Chief of the Golden Lake Band, accompanied by one of his Headmen, visited this Department yesterday to protest against the recent action of the Department in the matter, which, as you may remember, was to displace a Teacher (Miss Dunne) satisfactory to the Indians, and to replace her by one unsatisfactory to them (Mr. O'Brien). The Chief states that the Indians are not sending their children to the school because of Mr. O'Brien's incumbency of the position of Teacher, and will not do so while they feel that their wishes, which have for so long and so respectfully been represented, are, as the Indians feel, completely set at naught by the Department. He again respectfully begs that the situation may be changed, and that a Teacher satisfactory to the Indians may be appointed.

To compose the difficulty which arose between these Indians and their Agent over this matter of a Teacher, the Department early in the year adopted a suggestion made by its Inspector, who was sent to inquire into the matter, which was that the Agent's nominee should be removed after due notice, and that a female Teacher (which is what the Indians want, and what, as they say, their Priest desires them to have) should be appointed. Such appointment would not at that time necessarily have been given to Miss Dunne, the Indians' nominee, and a compromise which
which would have been a sufficient support to the Agent, and at once have sufficiently reasoned and sufficiently satisfied the Indians would have been effected.

The Indians now again request Mr. O'Brien's removal, and the appointment of a female Teacher.

The Department considers that the action of the Agent has not been dictated by a wise, tactful, and conciliatory spirit, and that the present cessation of education on the Reserve is largely due thereto, and thinks that the maintenance of Mr. O'Brien in the position would not only cause further difficulty in educational matters, but tend to increase the friction which unhappily exists between Mr. Indian Agent Bennett and the Indians under his charge. It is therefore strongly of the opinion that Mr. O'Brien's services should be dispensed with at the expiration of the term for which it is stated he has been engaged, that is to say, on the 31st of October next; and that a female Teacher, preferably Miss Dunne, who is reported to be capable, and who has suffered innocently in the matter, and whose lawyers—it may be mentioned—are making demands for past salary, be appointed in his stead; and the Department recommends that this course should be decided upon, and the intention to pursue it be at once communicated to the Indians, in order to set at rest the uneasiness now prevalent amongst them.

Will you be kind enough to intimate what steps you desire should ensue upon the representations of the Indian deputation referred to?

[Signature]

Deputy Superintendent General
of Indian Affairs.

Ottawa, 19th August, 1896.
Ottawa, 19th August, 1896.

Dear Mr. Scott,

I return the notes addressed by Mr. Thomas Mackie and Mr. M. Mackay to the Premier, and which you sent me today. In connection therewith I beg to inform you that Mr. O'Brien, who is referred to, took charge of the Indian School at Golden Lake last November. He was nominated for the position by the Agent and recommended by the School Inspector. He succeeded Miss Quinn, who resigned. Shortly after Mr. O'Brien's appointment a letter was received from the Rev. P.J. Dowdall, of Eganville, suggesting that the school should be put under a female teacher who would be more apt to give the Indian children the motherly training they so needed. Father Dowdall was informed that before the receipt of his letter a teacher had been appointed, but that in the event of a vacancy again occurring the Department would bear in mind his suggestion as to the advisability of engaging a female teacher. The Indians objected to Mr. O'Brien, and went so far at one time as to prevent his entering the school. In July last Chief Joseph Partridge informed the Department that at a general
meeting the Indians enquired why Miss Sophia Dunn, the teacher engaged by them the previous winter, had not been appointed. The Department felt that owing to the opposition of the Indians it was not desirable to continue Mr. O'Brien in the position and that if the school was to be made a benefit to the band it would be necessary to employ the person whom the Indians desired as a teacher, providing that she had the necessary qualifications. The Chief was accordingly told that Miss Dunn should forward through the Agent to the Department any testimonials and certificates which she had. Miss Dunn's certificate of qualification was accordingly forwarded to the Department, together with testimonials from the Rev. Father Chain and Mr. Inspector Scott, of Renfrew. These were satisfactory and Miss Dunn was engaged, her duties as teacher to begin on the 24th instant. Her salary is placed at $250 a year, $50 less than was paid Mr. O'Brien.

Yours very truly,

Hon. R.W. Scott,
Acting Superintendent General
of Indian Affairs.

The Secretary:

I beg to call your attention to Mr. Inspector O'Brien's report on the Golden Lake school from which you will see that he considers the work of the present teacher, Miss Lucinda Casey, of the crudest kind and although perhaps equal to the average Indian school teacher, he thinks that in such a small school so comfortably quartered and so pleasantly and centrally situated, the Department should experience no difficulty in obtaining the services of a skillful, energetic, Normal-trained teacher for the salary paid, which is $300.00 a year.

Miss Casey has had charge of this school since January 1900 and the children are deriving little, if any benefit from her tuition.

Miss Schruder, teacher of the Golden Lake School, has applied for an increase in salary from $450.00 to $500.00 per annum. MEMORANDUM

Mr. Scott,

I visited the school which is a neat nicely kept building. While there the teacher asked me to bring into the notice of the Department the lack of attendance. There were 35 on the roll with an attendance of 13 which she says is the average. I would recommend that someone be appointed truant officer with a small salary which I think would be money well spent, to try to have the children attend more regularly.

There is no well on the school property and the water has to be taken from the river about 300 yards from the school, and the teacher informed me that they could not use it in the warm weather as there are a number of summer cottages just above, and during the warm weather the shore is lined with campers who dispose of all their sewage in the river. I would recommend that a well be dug this winter as the soil is of a sandy nature and could be done more easily in cold weather.

The ground is unfir for garden purposes as the only vegetables that could be raised were potatoes of which twelve bags remain in the school house cellar. I would recommend that the stones be picked off the garden plot and a few loads of good earth supplied in time for the spring planting. The paint on the outside of the school is peeling off. The building would be better if...
another coat of paint this summer.

J. A. Robertson.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I am very sorry to have to report to you regarding the misconduct of one of my pupils, Percy Jocks, age 13 yrs., son of Seymour Jocks, in Grade II.

Last Thursday afternoon, Mar. 23rd, around 2:30 P.M., I called his class up for spelling. I took the spelling lesson. They had around seven words to spell, which were taken out of his Reading lesson. He had them all wrong but one, although the other pupil in the same class and only about half his age had...
no mistakes. I told him to take a seat nearer the front, as I felt he wasn't paying as much attention to his work at back, where he had been sitting, as he should. He went to the back seat, making no move to change. I told him again, but he just sat there. At last I went down to him and asked him again, but no answer. I tried to get him out of his seat but I couldn't move him. When trying to get him out of seat, he drew out his fist, in a terrible temper, hit my eye-glasses, broke them, and they cut me under the eye. Luckily I didn't get any glass in my eye, as far as I can see. He went home and told his father, the reason he
came home was, one of the children at school was teasing him.

I had to send my glasses to Sutherland and Parkins, Ottawa, where I expect it will cost me six -- $50 Dollars.

Now Mr. Hoey don't you think, a boy, with a temper like that, deserves some special punishment, as he is a bad example to other pupils?

Trusting you will be able to do something. Thanking you.

Yours sincerely,

Josephine Carrier,
Teacher Indian Day School,
Golden Lake, Ont.

I received tuition from Miss Currie myself and she appeared to me to know her work, but uses the method of coaxing the children along rather than driving them, of course a very strict teacher would run into a lot of difficulty. I think Miss Curriers letter is self explanatory.

Dear Miss MacNulty:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of October 14 and have noted with interest the statements contained therein.

May I state without hesitation that you are wholly in error when you state:

"I feel that as all your teachers have free quarters the Department should pay my room rent."

I can think of dozens of schools in Ontario and in the West where no accommodation whatever is provided for Indian day school teachers. I am not suggesting by any means that this is an ideal condition. I am simply submitting it as a statement of fact. Then, too, it does seem somewhat strange to me that these demands for additional accommodation should reach us at a time when this Nation is fighting for its very existence and when there appears to be an acute shortage of building materials and skilled construction workers.

May I point out also that Indian day school teachers and Civil Servants in the lower salary brackets qualify for the cost-of-living bonus. This bonus is not paid, however, to a great many Civil Servants whose salaries are a little higher and who have without protest accepted the higher cost of living as a patriotic duty. However, in view of all the circumstances, I am recommending that your salary be increased by $5.00 per month. It is my hope that this action on my part will prove satisfactory to you.

Yours sincerely,

R. A. Hosy,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Memorandum—

At the time of my visits to Golden Lake during the past year I have received many complaints from Indian women against the teacher Miss M. MacNulty.

At first I was of the opinion that as the complaints were of a trivial nature that through time they would correct themselves. This, however, is not the case. It appears that Miss MacNulty has aggravated conditions by discussing the family affairs amongst the children during class hours. The agent states that she was especially nasty to Mrs. J. Lavalley, and just before school closed it took him all of a week to iron out their differences. Mrs. Lavalley at the time was threatening to leave the reserve. This, in my opinion, would be serious as Mrs. Lavalley has been very actively engaged working among members of the Homemaker's Club assisting and advising Indian women in the improvement of their homes, gardens, care of chickens, remodelling clothing, etc.

I hesitated to investigate these minor complaints as I felt that they would be magnified way out of proportion. I am convinced, however, in spite of the good classroom work being accomplished by Miss MacNulty, that in the interests of the Golden Lake Indians her services as teacher there should not be continued for another term.

I would recommend that an effort be made to obtain another teacher.

J. E. Morris,

Re: Engagement of Golden Lake Indian Day School.

I wish to inform you that we now have thirty-nine pupils attending the Golden Lake Indian Day School. To accommodate this number of pupils we are utilizing every bit of space in the classroom. The extra number of pupils who have recently entered the school are children of families who were living away from the Reserve during the war years, and have now moved back. There is a possibility that more families will move back to the Reserve in the near future.

Taking these families into consideration along with the children now on the Reserve who will be old enough to start school in the autumn, I find that we will have an enrolment of between forty-five and fifty in the school before any of the present pupils have either reached the age of sixteen or passed their entrance. Therefore the present school will have to be enlarged to two rooms to accommodate this many. I would suggest that an official from the Training Division visit this Agency in the near future to inspect the school and see what can be done with regard to an additional classroom.

Re: GOLDEN LAKE INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.

I acknowledge your letter of April 29th, last, with regard to a second classroom in the Golden Lake Indian Day School.

In answer I wish to inform you that we will definitely have 44 pupils in the school for the academic year 1946-47. In addition to this number it is quite possible that Indian families, who have been living away from the Reserve during the War years, may move back. If this happens then our school attendance may reach well over the fifty mark. This sudden increase in the number of pupils attending this school is partially due to the Family Allowance regulations which says that a child has to start school at six years of age when formerly Indian children started when they were seven or eight years old. Also as I stated in my previous letter a number of Indian families have moved back to their homes on the Reserve. This increase was unforeseen when making the estimates for 1946-47. The classroom now in this school normally holds about twenty-seven pupils but by using chairs and tables and every inch of available space we have an attendance of thirty-nine.

In your letter you suggested that a building be rented, on the Reserve, which could be used as a classroom for the coming year. With regard to this I wish to inform you that all available buildings are being used as homes and with the exception of the Community hall and storehouse (which we intend to complete this summer) there is no other building which we could use. By raising the roof on the present school a second classroom might be built above at less cost than building a new wing; also save cost in heating. However I would like to have an official of the Training Division visit the school before making any recommendation.

Your obedient servant,

H.F. Reddy
Indian Agent.

Mr. J. T. Anderson, Separate School Inspector for South Renfrew, and also Inspector of the Golden Lake Indian Day School, sent this Programme to Miss Legris. The notation at the bottom was made by Mr. Anderson. According to this notation, this will be the only Teachers' Convention that will be held this year and as I did not have time to write you regarding the attendance of the teachers of the Golden Lake Indian Day School at this Convention, I took the liberty of giving them permission to attend. I hope that this will meet with your approval for as far as I know this is the first Teachers' Convention that has been held in this county since early in the war.

I would like to know whether November 11th will be a School holiday. It is not mentioned in the list of holidays in Circular # C-150-48 but I understand that it will be a holiday in the Public Schools of Ontario.

Your obedient servant,

H. P. Ruddy,
Indian Agent.
Golden Lake, Ontario.
October 24th, 1946.

Chief, Training Division,
Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ont.

RE: OPENING OF SECOND CLASSROOM
AT GOLDEN LAKE INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.

I wish to inform you that we opened the second classroom of the Golden Lake Indian Day School. Miss Sullivan started to teach in the Community Hall on the Reserve on Monday, October 21st, and she has Grades I, II, and III in this classroom. She has a total of 25 pupils in these three Grades (II boys and 14 girls). Miss Legris, the principal, is teaching Grades VI, VII, and VIII and has 21 pupils (12 boys and 9 girls) in the old school.

I had to get some additional equipment for this second classroom which included, 2 brooms; 1 dustpan; 1 water pail; 1 washbasin; 1 alarm clock for classroom; and 2 padlocks for the toilet doors. The total cost of these articles was $7.95.

Your obedient servant,

H. F. Ruddy,
Indian Agent.

Memorandum:

CHIEF TREASURY OFFICER.

Re: Golden Lake Indian Day School No. 394.

Under the provisions of the new salary schedule, the Department has classified the two teachers at the above school, effective September 1, 1948, as follows:

(a) Miss Margaret Legris as a Grade 3 teacher at a salary of $1950, an academic year. She has been given credit for a First Class Certificate, ten years' Provincial School Experience and three years' Indian School Experience. (MR-IAE-394-3001).

(b) Miss Marie Sullivan as a Grade 2 teacher at a salary of $1750, an academic year. She has been given credit for a Second Class Certificate, three years' experience in Provincial Schools and two years' experience in Indian Schools. (MR-IAE-394-3002).

Ottawa, July 28, 1921

Madam,-

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 25th instant, regarding your salary and bonus cheques for the quarter ending June 30th.

In reply I beg to say that cheque No. 933 for $187.50, being the amount of salary due as teacher of the Golden Lake Day School for the above period, was sent you at Golden Lake on the 23rd instant. You will, no doubt, receive it by making enquiries from the postmaster at that point. Also your bonus cheque for the same period was sent you by ck. No. 1758 for $45.00 on the 22nd instant addressed to Mr. Patrick Rankins. It is hoped that you have received it by this date.

I may add that the bonus for the present fiscal year is being paid at the rate of $15.00 per month for the ten teaching months and that is the rate at which you have been paid for the June quarter.

Your obedient servant

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Assistant Deputy and Secretary

Miss Josephine Currier
Eganville,
Ont.

Dear Sir:

Today I received my cheque No. 245-9 for the amount of twenty-five dollars. This is in payment for the September quarter for teaching in the school.

The amount I should have received was One hundred and eighty-seven dollars. My year in the first class started from Sept. 1st and I was to receive a salary $750 per annum paid.
quarterly at the rate of $187.50 every three months. I have not received all my salary for last year, I am still minus of $187.50. All the other teachers around here are receiving $900 surely the Government cannot afford to pay $900 without at least pay what is coming to the teacher.

Kindly look into this matter as soon as possible.

And oblige,

Ottawa, October 18, 1923.

ENCLOSURE.

Madam,-

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 15th instant, with reference to the amount of salary sent you for the month of September.

In reply I beg to say that it has been decided to pay the salaries of day school teachers, in future, on the basis of ten teaching months in the school year. In this connection I enclose for your information copy of circular letter of the 17th ultimo, which was forwarded to all Indian agents and teachers.

Your salary is at the rate of $750.00 a year, plus bonus. The amount, therefore, due you for September was 1/10 of $750.00, or, $75.00. At the end of the other quarters in the school year, you will be paid $225.00, plus the bonus in each case.

Miss Josephine Carrier consulted me about five weeks ago to have a feeling replaced. At time she consulted me I noticed her in a very nervous condition. I drew her attention to the fact that she had absorption in her system due to pyorrhea condition surrounding many of her teeth. She then told me she was under medical treatment & was unable to open up her school when school reopened. I advised her to consult Dr. Copeland & see if he would verify my statement. He found her condition required immediate attention which she consulted too. I believe it nothing a splendid recovery. His Excellency

The Governor General in Council.

The undersigned has the honour to report that Parliament voted $200.00 towards the construction of a school house on the Golden Lake Reserve, in the County of Renfrew, Ontario, and that the Indians of that Reserve, who have at their credit in the hands of the Department, $220.78 capital, and $9.70 interest, have expressed their willingness that the amount required for the completion of the school, over and above the appropriation made by Parliament, should be taken from their funds. After expending the Parliamentary appropriation there will be an unpaid balance of $170.86 on account of the building. It is estimated that $47.00 will be required for seats, and $7.00 for shutters, making the whole amount required for the completion of the school $224.86.

The undersigned would respectfully recommend that the authority of Your Excellency in Council be given for the expenditure of the $224.86 required for the completion of the school from the money at the credit of the Golden Lake Indians.

Superintendent General

Agreement made in duplicate the 15th day of May A.D. 1912.

Between His Majesty King George the Fifth, represented by the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs of Canada (hereinafter called the Superintendent General);

And Messrs. Tait & Devlin of the town of Eganville in the province of Ontario (hereinafter called the Contractor).

The Contractor for himself, his heirs, executors, administrators and assigns, agrees to do in the most workmanlike manner all works and provide all the materials of the best kind shown in the drawings and described in the specifications marked "A" and "B" respectively and signed by the Contractor, and to complete, furnish and hand over to the Superintendent General or to some person by him appointed for that purpose, the frame school-house to be erected on the Golden Lake Indian Reserve near Golden Lake Station, Ontario and all other work and labour incidental to and necessary for the entire completion thereof, whether specified or shown in the drawings or specifications or not, by the fifteenth day of August A.D. 1912.

AND in consideration of the above agreement on the part of the Contractor, the Superintendent General hereby agrees to pay the said Contractor the sum of two thousand, seven hundred and fifty-nine dollars, provided always that the Superintendent General may at any time during the progress or after the completion or alleged completion of the work, appoint an Architect, Engineer or other officer, in which case the certificate of such Architect, Engineer or other officer, that the work is duly completed and of the amount, if any due, to the Contractor, after making such allowances for penalties and for defective or incomplete work, or for extras and deviations as the Architect, Engineer or other officer shall think fair, shall be a condition precedent to any claim by the Contractor under this contract.

AND the Contractor for himself, his executors, administrators and assigns, further covenants and agrees:

1. That the wages to be paid in the execution of this contract shall be those generally accepted as current in each trade for competent workmen in the district where the work is carried on. If this condition is violated, the Superintendent General may cancel the contract and refuse to accept any work done thereunder.

2. That if the Contractor fails at any time to pay any account for any goods or materials supplied, or money advanced by anyone to the said Contractor for the purposes of this agreement, or to pay the account of any sub-contractor for any work or materials done or supplied for the said works to be constructed under this agreement, and such
account is in either of such cases one month overdue, the Superintendent General may notify the Contractor to pay such account, and if a week elapse and the same be not paid in full, the Superintendent General may pay such account and may charge the same to the Contractor, and the Contractor covenants with the Superintendent General to repay at once any and every sum so paid.

3. That if the Contractor fails at any time in paying salaries or wages of any person employed by him upon or in respect of the said work, or any of them, and any part of such salary is one month in arrear, or if there be due to any such person one month's wages or salary, the Superintendent General may notify the Contractor to pay such salary or wages, and if he does not do so, the same shall be paid in full up to date of payment; or to such other date as may be in accordance with the terms of employment of such person, then the Superintendent General may pay to such person his salary or wages from any date to any date and to any amount which may be payable, and may charge the same to the Contractor, and the Contractor covenants with the Superintendent General to repay at once any and every sum so paid.

4. That pursuant to the Statute in that behalf, this Agreement is made subject to the express condition that no member of the House of Commons of Canada shall be admitted to any share or part of this Agreement or any benefit to arise therefrom.

5. That the Contractor shall not assign, transfer or set over this contract or any interest therein to any person or persons whomsoever, without the consent, in writing, of the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs first had and obtained.

The hot air registers in the wall should be placed at the floor rather than where shown on the plan some six feet above the floor line.
